number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Planetary Annihilation seems to be a hot button right now for how "Early Access" games should be released. I want to objectively discuss that point, the devs support of the game, and its current state. (build 77443)First off, I want to say that I love this game. I bought this game in earl alpha and have been pretty active with it as I can get with an RTS. The thing about PA is that its not the average RTS. Its not Starcraft, Grey Goo, Etherium, or even Supreme Commander. PA is a huge game, it has no unit cap, and the only 'research' you need for higher teir units is to build the required factory. This structure for an RTS supports a different playstyle. So lets look at the simple, "is this game for you?" -myeah-maybe... The lack of a tech tree seems to be a deterrent for some, so if you want the slow build up for complicated tactical gameplay, you may need to look a little closer at PA. I've played this game competitively, casually, with friends, by myself, and pretty much everything. Its possible to set up planets and solar systems, so I've even messed around with scenario games, like all Navy or an Air Force only game with friends. I've genuinely enjoyed all of this. It has offered me my money's worth for sure.Competitive: PA is micro-intensive. You need to constantly be checking everything you're trying to do. Camera hotkeys and anchors help with your interplanetary wars. That aside, nearly all competitive matches I've played has gone a T1 battle, between combinations of the T1 units, when the casual really well matched battles can go on for 40 minutes. The 1v1 ranked matches are played on mirrored, pre built maps. I don't see this as a problem, in fact, I welcome it. Most RTS's have this map structure to make the playing field even. Their are plenty of strategies in competitive. Of course you have your META, Aniti-META, Anti-Anti-META, but PA lets you focus on heavy minor strategies like choosing whether you want to bomber harass, build up those turrets, get a more respectable army, rush that early expansion, maybe try all at once and plunge your economy, etc. You can mold your playstyle to fit PA. Casual: I defiantly wouldn't reccomend PA to anyone who has never played a RTS, and expect them to enjoy thier time. Like any game as micro intensive as this, PA can be a little frusturating to players who stick to fighting the AI. That being said, once you ramp up the AI, it can get pretty-friggin challenging. of course, you can put the AI on normal and toy with them any way you want. The galactic war mode is okay, nothing super new, but you can make a campaign out of it if you want.With friends: Really fun if everyone is ready to lose. Teaming up with a few friends to fight 3 bots on the hardest difficulty is a nice experience, full of tears and suffering, and sometimes, triumph. Then killing your friends with 30+ nukes is also interesting. Dynamic Alliances in FFA games make for some interesting real time diplomacy. Really fun game with friends. about 30 hours (i have ~95 at time of posting) is just with friends.Singleplayer: I don't have much to say after what I've already discussed. Load up a bot game, play the Galactic War mode, run some scenarios. Make it your own.Now I want to just touch on the aspects of the game that are discussed in about every other review here. Music - Fantastic, want soundtrack. 9/10Graphics - Fun artstyle that I personally enjoy, looks great. 8/10Personalization - Purchase the commanders that the backers made (I'll talk about this in the next section.) Commanders are generally nice looking, get to pick your own. No special effects on commanders, e.g. one doesn't have faster build speed or fly. That is nice. 6.5/10UI - Used to be jumbled, now much nicer. 9/10Now lets talk about how the release was handled. I was generally just a spectator because I had already bought the game, but I agree with most people saying that it should not be in 'full release' yet. Constant updates keep coming, and the community is alive. It feels like a finished game at most points, but it can have its issues. Luckily devs are constantly on it. The big fuss about all of this is due to the fact that this was a crowd funded game. This makes people complain when they see that the uniqe, player created commanders cost some money (personally I think a bit too much, but who am I?) but again, crowd funded, they supported first, they have privilages, these kind of games are fres from DAY ONE DLC GET THE GAME EARLY GET SNOOP DOG MARIJUANA GUN PACKS MTN DEWRITOS, so be happy about that. To be honest, I don't really care - but the topic has to be discussed. Early access games are a breed of their own, and people need to realize that they aren't going to be done when in development. Some people say PA is still in dvelopment, I wouldn't necessarily disagree, but if the title of 'released' bothers you that much, you may need to go to another game. But who cares about all of that? you just want a number. I give it a 7.5/10. I'll keep playing. New things keep popping up, and I like the dev team. Come back and buy it during a sale if you are skeptic. It drops to around 6-7$ so pick it up then if ever. If you don't want something where all of the tactics include where you place your base components and how you use your units, and want something a bit slower, but more in-depth - go check out Wargame Red Dragon, Grey Goo, and Etherium. They are all relatively new, look good, and have their own quirks.

Early Access Review
								I know its early release, but feels like I wasted money on a Supreme Commander clone that is not nearly as good or smooth as SC1. So many things are missing, and its just awkward to control - I just gave up because you get pummeled - not because you aren't building well, but the controls are brutal! Scroll a bit with your mouse wheel and you're so zoomed out you can't see anything. You can't find units unless you are zoomed in very far, and meanwhile you're trying to scroll back across your round planet, to find your units, you're getting squashed because it took you a minute to find your troops. Its too bad - I love RTS games, but unless this gets a lot of improvement, I'm back to Supreme Commander and Sins....sigh, so much lost potential.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												As an original Kickstarter of this game I feel robbed of my $50 that I foolishly gave them. Thanks to Uber Entertainment, I will never Kickstart another game. For some reason, Uber decided to split the community up by creating a new stand-alone game called Titans, therefore the Vanilla version is completely dead and is no longer supported or updated. The game is still riddled with bugs: achievements do not unlock, cannot build in 5th Catalyst spot, units freeze up and do not respond, terrible pathfinding, etc.). As well as the game has terrible performance and terrible AI. By the way, you have to always be connected to their servers in order to play the game, and their servers have been down which you are out of luck if you want to play. The overall gameplay feels like this game should be $20 at most, and not the $40/$50 pricetag they are trying to sell it for. The gameplay at times is very stagnant and bland, however the musical score is excellent and it's a shame that such beautifully orchestrated music is in such a terrible game. There is no campaign, however there is a Galatic War mode which essentially is just a bunch of random skirmishes tied together with the player starting off with little to no technology and after every battle you will slowly increase your technology. After a few battles in Galatic War mode it's the same thing over and over and becomes very tedious. Finally, the loading time is ridiculously long for games in this day and age - it literally takes more than a couple of minutes to populate the world and to load your commander in. Do yourself and everyone a favor and skip this game, it's not worth it at all.

												So basically if you start out getting your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you, you can literally with one man left turn the odds around. If you are skilled enough and or think smart, this game has endless possibilities. The controls are smooth once you get used to it, everything just flows. You can have an endless army that's just massive!    My 2nd 1v1 game I played I rocked this dude. he wiped my army out but I had enough time to get a launch pad and get my commander to the Planetary destroyer planet or what ever its called. I got him there and immediately expanded resources and massed bombers and executed planet wide patrols so this guy could not land on my planet.. well I accidentally over looked a small part of the planet were he was able to plant a teleportation building and transferred at least 400 to 500 units. I immediately gathers all bombers and fighters, I positioned all my fighters to go in first and take the first wave of AA attacks then sent in my bombers in one quick strafe run my bombers took out ALL of the units and destroyed the teleportation device I immediately beefed up on my orbital patrol units and what ever he sent in after I destroyed and this was on going until i finally gained control of my Planetary destroyer.  He mass sent at least 6 to 7 nukes but luckily I knew he was going to do that because it was just commons sense he had no other options or crash his planet into mine.  so i made ANTI nuke missile's. GG his planet was wiped and I win and he raged. turned out he was like over 100 plus games in and it was my 2nd. GLORIOUS!  This game has endless possibilities and you will always have something to counter anyone's military so choose wisely. content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												I got this game in a bundle for like 3€ most (the whole bundle, not the game) and I still feel ripped off. The saddest thing is that the concept of this game is brilliant. It's just terribly executed.One of the biggest selling points of the game is that you can have a whole system and have a match where you not only have to fight the enemy, you also have to figure out where in the system they are. Sounds great, right? Yeah it should. The problem is, the moment you have a system that big (9+ planets) the game becomes unplayable, ranging between 1 and 14 FPS and with planets not rendering fully. My GTX 970 can run any modern game (Witcher 3, SW: Battlefront, etc) in Ultra at 50-60 FPS with no sweat. However even when I overclock it, it cannot run Planetary Annihilation at more than 14FPS when playing in a full system. The game looks barely better than a mobile game, the fact that it's far more demanding than games like Witcher 3 or SW: Battlefront (even at low a graphic setting) is simply absurd.If you have a GTX 1080 or better than you can still get this game, but don't get such a high-end GPU just for PA. It's not worth it. If you don't have such a high-end GPU avoid it. It will bring you nothing but headaches.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
Early Access Review
								I've first fell in love in love with the strategy game genre with Warcraft then Command & Conquer and Red Alert I dropped a stupid amount of hours of my child hood into these games. I've played many titles like ZZ Soldier, Starcraft, Heroes of Might & Magic, Age of Empires, Civilization & Alpha Centari, Homeworld and etc. The one title that seemed to steal my soul was Total Annihilation.You might be uhhh I've never heard of that title. Was that a starcraft knockoff? Not even quite. Yea it was futuristic but that was it. It was one of the first fully 3d strategy game even if they had to secure the camera view to overhead because of deisgn problems and being overcomplicated. (TAspring is what it would have been like..) Every fired projectile had physics afffecting it and the cpu would track it + million other processes. There's more to say here but Im cutting it short. I spend days online on the boneyard ( in game multiplayer service which I've never seen the likes of before and still to this day have not) then Mplayer, then when that service crashed I spent my remainder days on Game Spy Arcade when not using tcp/ip connections with clan mates. This was an early game that made it easier to mod and accepted modding, which popped my mod cherry. To my dismay I never knew a game could be changed like that by a user!Then Supreme Commander came out which Chris Taylor the project lead of TA started that with some of the old crew of Cavedog (developer of TA) made another great addition to the franchise. Even though there was more to be improved but I spent a stupid amount of my young adult life playing it 19 to present(26). Now you have Planetary Annihilation. Alot of people from primordial ages of Cavedog and the newer employees from Gas Powered Games are making a new love child of Total Annihilation. There's brilliant ideas with the game but with it still in beta I cannot give a concrete review about it. If you love massive scale strategy in real time and space this might tickle your fancy.  I cannot wait til the team takes their time and finish this title. It could be another A+++ title like Total Annihilation or better!

number of helpful: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												In my opinion, this is the most revolutionary leap forward ever made in the RTS genre. Nothing else comes close.Learning lessons from their past games (Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander), the developers have reinvented this style of RTS with a completely new paradigm: inter-planetary warfare, which means spherical maps (no hiding in corners), and the ability to destroy entire planets. In this new spiritual successor, the interface and economy have both been streamlined and simplified, while still keeping to their original spirit. The elimination of micromanagement has been a fundamental design goal from the beginning, and the developers have largely succeeded.One of the most significant features is the Chrono Cam, which gives the ability to jump to any point in a replay, or even a game that you're still playing. You can go back and forward in time, and even play the game in reverse. It's seamless and works extremely well. This Chrono Cam, in its entirety, is something that no other game studio has ever made.The game can be difficult at first, and there is a high bar for multiplayer gameplay, but there is an excellent integrated replay system that will let you watch anyone's games, even the top-tier ranked games, so you can improve rapidly.The interface is extremely powerful, which moves the emphasis away from micro-management to macro. This gives the greatest thinkers an advantage over the fastest clickers. This focus separates this game from most other real-time strategies, making it more about higher-order planning than quick reaction time.The strategies can get quite diverse with 4 "planes" of combat: Land, Water, Air and Orbital. I often end up fighting battles on multiple planets simultaneously in bigger games, but if this isn't your thing, you can limit your play to small single-planet systems.If you liked Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander, but are looking for a game with the potential for longevity, you'll find it here. If you've never heard of those games and are in to the RTS genre, you'll find this completely different from anything you've seen before.I've been waiting 15 years for this game, and I'm really happy with how it turned out.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												So I bought this game and actually enjoyed it, it's a solid RTS with mechanics never seen before, it has Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander spirit, but lacks in some of the good aspects of both those games. However, it does some things that those previous titles did not. You might say this should be a positive review. But it's not.I bought this game back in the last summer sale. I've been wanting to get it since it was announced in kickstarter but the exchange rate in my country is quite steep (multiply by 10 every price you see here) and I had to wait for a sale and for it to be "finished" and/or "polished" enough to merit the purchase. Keep in mind that I'm not a fan of Early Access and all that it implies (paying for a game without the guarantee that it'll be finished or it will deliver what was promised).Yesterday UBER launched TITANS (the unannounced "expansion" that  doesn't expand anything  because it's standalone) which for us that bought the original PA is literally a big finger in all orifices. You might say "but hey, you get a discount!" yeah... I get a 66% discount that leaves a $40 game (that I already own) at DLC price, with the knowledge that if I don't buy it  I will never get an update  on that same game (vanilla PA)  AT ALL . And I don't mean those Titan units and whatnot. I mean actual performance, bug, optimization fixes and updates. Basically all I get from this is that they discontinued support UNLESS I buy the game again. This could've been a DLC and noone would be ranting like this. But no, rebuy the game, guys.That's the worst business ethics I've seen in a while, and even worse the "standalone DLC/Update" Titans is getting good reviews for some reason. I hope the press doesn't keep praising it and consumers don't buy into this company's ways of treating us. I for one, will pirate it if I ever want to play it, these guys won't get a dime from me again. If you plan to buy Titans, do so, i'm sure it's good, but do it with caution, you never know what Uber might pull in the future.

												So this game is okay. I'm more of a single-player/couch coop and the single player mode is a bit underwhelming compared with the extensive campaign modes of its predecessors like Total Annihilation. You'd probably get more mileage if you're into But anyway, this review is going to be more about the recent conduct of the developers Uber Entertainment. They've just released PA:Titans - which is the same basic game, plus a few more units - essentially what would be a $5 DLC for any other game. But because the original PA has a 67/33 split of good and bad reviews (enough to show up as 'Mixed Reviews' and Metacritic scores of 62 and 57, it appears they've  basically relaunched the entire game as a "Standalone Expansion Pack" for $40, albeit with freebies for Kickstarter backers, and a discount for EA buyers.It's the sort of shady♥♥♥♥♥♥move that you expect from the big publishing houses, and if that's how Uber choose to conduct themselves, they won't be seeing any more of my money.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												To be honest, it’s extremely similar to Supreme Commander.Despite all the negative reviews for this game, I believe it's worth buying. Not like many games, this game is regularly updated and sharing news and polls. Right now, it’s obvious that this game still needs some work. Some of the AI of the units and commander itself needs some improvements, some rendering issues here and there, and other bugs can be fixed.Though, despite the known issues, this is a very good looking game. Rendering and the lighting in this game is remarkable, and I haven't seen such great lighting in games for a while now until I came across this one. The aspect of this game is fun, and easy to get used too, and single player can be fun as well, as long as you have an internet connection.So, at its current stage, it is playable, but do expect to see some bugs and issues yourself.Therefore, I recommend this game for those of you who are familiar with RTS games, and those of you who don't expect too highly in games like these. - BlueRemember: to those of you who are thinking twice, this game is indeed need of improvements, but Uber Entertainment is already working on these issues. Check back eventually, and you can expect some changes.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												This game is pitched all wrong.  The hook isn't death stars or planet-smashing - the hook is that this the only RTS with strategic zoom on spherical maps. Spherical maps! I can't overemphasize how much of a game-changer these are! One you experience a battle not on one front, not on multple fronts, but on multiple connected circular fronts, you'll have a hard time going back to your standard flat-map RTS fare. It doesn't hurt that it looks gorgeous too. And there's a stripped down, focused tech tree that makes every unit unique and useful (no experimental spam here). And there's even a thriving mod scene with a 1-click-to-install mod database app to go along with it. Not to mention built-in multiplayer hosting, matchmaking, and a global replay library. Oh yeah, AND death stars and planet smashing. I picked this up for cheap at the last sale with low expectations - knowing only that it was generally considered unfinished. Liked what I found enough to buy a bunch of useless in-game commander skins to support continued updates. I definitely underpaid up front for the amount of fun I'm having, and there are more updates coming!There's some rough edges and features still missing, but the core game is all that counts and that's where PA shines. If fast paced Supcom gameplay with powerful, customizable controls on multiple spherical planetoids sounds fun to you, that's because it is.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												To be honest, it’s extremely similar to Supreme Commander.Despite all the negative reviews for this game, I believe it's worth buying. Not like many games, this game is regularly updated and sharing news and polls. Right now, it’s obvious that this game still needs some work. Some of the AI of the units and commander itself needs some improvements, some rendering issues here and there, and other bugs can be fixed.Though, despite the known issues, this is a very good looking game. Rendering and the lighting in this game is remarkable, and I haven't seen such great lighting in games for a while now until I came across this one. The aspect of this game is fun, and easy to get used too, and single player can be fun as well, as long as you have an internet connection.So, at its current stage, it is playable, but do expect to see some bugs and issues yourself.Therefore, I recommend this game for those of you who are familiar with RTS games, and those of you who don't expect too highly in games like these. - BlueRemember: to those of you who are thinking twice, this game is indeed need of improvements, but Uber Entertainment is already working on these issues. Check back eventually, and you can expect some changes.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												A quite different RTS. Play on spherical planets. And blow them up. Use hundreds of units of all kinds. Fight on land, sea, air and orbital space. What other game lets you do that?While you're browsing trough these reviews, ignore all reviews from september and october. Lots of issues have been fixed since release, and good new stuff such as ranked multiplayer, the Unit Cannon, offline mode and player guide have been added through updates. These old reviews are seriously outdated. The developers will keep adding and fixing things, they have absolutely not abandoned this game. The micro-transactions are purely cosmetic and have no gameplay impact. Plus by purchasing commanders, high tier KS backers get a small amount of money for their commander sales. The current problems that the game has is no saving and Galactic War is a bit unpolished and boring. Balance is also not that great, but still good. But those are issues that can be addressed in updates and I'm sure Uber will do so. Also managing multiple planets is quite hectic, though that is something that is harder to fix.What's really good about the game is the ability to construct units without a limit, you can have hundreds if not more than a thousand on the field(s). The planets are randomly generated and you can blow them up by smashing one into another one or by using the Annihilaser of doom. The orchestral soundtrack is also pretty epic. The AI is smart, propably one of the best (that doesn't cheat (except on "absurd"))  in an RTS ever.What are you waiting for? Go blow up some planets!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												System: one planet, one moon (but no metal on it).Players: Me vs AIThinking the AI's gonna ship it's Commander off planet ASAFP, I break neck and chain to go orbital first, and carry my Commander over to the moon.I get a teleport going between the two planets and send over some T2 fabbers to get some off-planet power generation.Meanwhile at the home planet I'm holding my own BUT the AI has most of the outlying MEX (metal extractors).Then♥♥♥♥♥♥ Contact on the moon. In fact a whole mother♥♥♥♥ing swarm is on the other side of the moon. He got their too and stealthed up a proxy base - I should've had roaming scouts on that♥♥♥♥♥♥So I get a good force through the teleport and start building some T2 (Tier 2) anti-air stations on the moon.Then I think,♥♥♥♥♥♥ I bet he moved his commander on to the moon! He's vulnerable!So I get a nuke going, send a couple scouts out to find the commander but they're instantly shot before they can see enough.I send a few T2 vehicles on their way to their proxy moon base so that they can clean up.I fire the nuke, it hits. My three or four T2 vehicles get there. It's ground zero, BUT, a mother♥♥♥♥ing "Austreus" is dropping THE AI'S COMMANDER ONTO THE MOON. He had JUST begun to arrive when the nuke hit.I'm like♥♥♥♥♥♥ This is it! My vehicles start shooting him but he ♥♥♥♥ing lays into them and the small group ♥♥♥♥ing blows up!So i'm like♥♥♥♥♥♥ Here come the cavalry! I send EVERYTHING I have on my moon base toward him, then I realize... they're all T2 vehicles: aka slow as♥♥♥♥♥♥They get there to find... THE MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING COMMANDER SLINKING HIS WAY INTO A TELEPORT HE'D JUST BUILT. BACK TO THE HOME BASE. THAT♥♥♥♥♥♥ OMFG. I'd murder.My home base is still well fortified and I've amassed quite a T2 army but he still controls most of the MEX.So i'm real♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥now. But I have an idea. I want to lure the commander back, so I leave their teleport on the moonGet another nuke going. And periodically scout their proxy moon base.Sure enough, they start rebuilding it. But the Commander is still no where to be seen.I'M TRYING TO COAX HIM OUT BUT HE JUST DOESNT ♥♥♥♥ING COME.So I'm like that's it ♥♥♥♥♥. I'm coming to you.My nuke is ready. They probably have anti-nukes - but ♥♥♥♥ IT. On the off chance they don't, I want his head on a platter served to be by some guy with a French accent offering his finest wine to massage my pallet.Okay, I try to scout the location on the main planet so I can find the Command and aim my nuke accordingly but but again none of them get through. I fire the nuke pretty blind, with my army on the edge, ready to rush in once it's landed.The nuke weaves through the orbits and lands on the AI's base.My guys rush in... slowly... because they're largely T2 vehicles. They mow down everything in their path.Find the commander. He is severely damaged. And WHAT do you think that ♥♥♥♥ER is doing? HE'S BUILDING ANOTHER MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING TELEPORT. TRYING TO GET TO THE MOON.NOT THIS TIME♥♥♥♥♥♥My force wipes the floor with him.The mushroom cloud is satisfying.I then realize how much I got emotionally invested in the persual of his demise.Game ends at 70 minutes.9/11 would play again.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												I didnt get the memo that it was released, and if you play it, you won't think it was, either.The unit pathing is bad, original Supreme Commander levels of bad, getting stuck on walls and needing to be babysat in order to manage the slightest obstacle without causing a 12-lane pileup getting around a rock.The units are bare-bones, with 2 tiers, basic and advanced; there are "factions" in the campaign but the difference between them are the colours of the units and nothing else, leading to shallow gameplay and maybe 1 or 2 dominant strategies in ranked.Orbital gameplay is sparse, consisting of space rush, spam superiority fighters, set to patrol and repeat, if the other guy gets into orbit before you, pray he ruined his economy doing so or you've already lost if there's an off-world superweapon on the map.And now, there's a £20 expansion, adding all the things I paid £20 for about half a year ago to support being put in "in the development cycle"Do yourself a favour and buy Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, better unit variety, tech system, economy, and a dev console to mess around with if you get bored. Oh, and about £15 cheaper if you get it on sale.TL;DR: Uber did a DoubleFine, classic bait-and-switch. Buy SupCom:FA for a better RTS

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Summary - game is alright, netcode is good, lobby netcode is awfulSo i've played this game over 10 hours now and actually have quite an alright time once i make it into a game. The problem is finding and connecting to said multiplayer games. I'm frequently connected to an empty game, occasionally the game crashes and my computer just siezes up if i connect to larger games... and there's not even many people playing at any one time, over half the hosted games are passworded. Campaign is just a series of skirmishes against idiot AIs, no fun to be had there.nitpicking - the multiplayer browser's filter list needs work. even on my 1920x1080 screen the filters run off of the bottom of the screen, and every time you fail to connect to a game you need to apply those filters again. I got the game for free and i don't think i'd have been happy paying money for it!

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												Pros: Fun gameplaySomething different, it’s not the same as other rts games.A surprisingly good single playerDoesn’t get boring fast Cons:Server Issues Low population of players Lack of recent updates Planetary Annihilation is a really fun game and it really doesn’t get boring because of the custom planets and scenarios you’ll find yourself in. The gameplay is fun; there are many super weapons like nukes, unit launchers, Orbital Lasers and more stuff. The interplanetary mechanics are pretty good too, it’s always fun to spread out your empire and dominate the enemy. The single player too, is pretty good and fun but at the Normal difficulties, I personally think it’s too easy.Despite this, the game has some minor server lag issues, but I’d say that this is because of people abusing huge maps and making a 2v2v2v2v2 lobby with 10 planets. Obviously there will be some issues, though saying that, the issues are not that bad. Just some response lag (probably 200 – 400ms). And yet another problem is the lack of players, while recently it was on a free giveaway (I didn’t get the game for free, I bought it a year and a half ago), the player base has increased but i doubt it will stay. There hasn’t been an update for about 5 months but there a rumours that a patch is coming out soon for both Pa and Pa:Titans.Optimisation:Personally I don’t understand the problems some people have with optimisation with this game. My laptop has a core i7 cpu with intel hd 5500 and 8gb of ram and it can play the game at 40 fps in medium settings.Titans:Planetary Annihilation: Titans is an expansion pack, which costs 13 euros for people who already have the base game, which isn’t bad. The expansion its self, adds around 21 units, I can’t say more about the expansion pack since I haven’t got around to buying it yet. Uber:Uber entertainment developed the game. Uber is a small company; I doubt that they have anything more that 3-5 employes. This explains the lack of updates. And very few of the players still play the game. According to steamdb, pa (which has sold 1,000,000 copies, but only 73% of that have ever actually played the game), only 8.79% players have played the game in the last 2 weeks, which is not a lot for a multiplayer rts game. I recommend this game to anybody who likes rts games, it can be played casualy and competitively. I'd ignore most of the negative reviews since they're just reviews from people that have unconditional hatred towards Uber. The game is perfectly fine and will improve if it gets support.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
Early Access Review
If you want to lose friends, buy this game.It was a warm, sunny day, the birds were chirping and all was well. "JARHEAD!", said the Dan with a force of a million Roberts. "AM I GOING TO WASTE MY MONEY ON YOU?!", he said. It took hours upon hours of conversation to finally get the Dan to buy me Planetary Annihilation, and at last, he did, and all was well, for now....The first game, I was taught how to play the game, it didn't seem that hard for me, but Dan HAD to spend an hour teaching me. Once I finally grasped the concept of the game, I challenged him to a duel. It started off fine, I made a few metal extractors here, some energy plants there, it was all well. I didn't say anything about my strategy, eventually, I had a whole army built up of millions of little bomber planes, I spent hours making my millitia. I was ready to nuke the living $hit out of him, when he says, "Ahhh, the sweet smell of destruction." Before I knew it....BOOM!Everything.My army.My commander.My metal extractors.My friends.All dead.Every.Last.One.I left the game, went into the skype call, shared my screen, and let that mother&$%#er watch me uninstall it.I have very little patience.For the love of god, buy this game, you will like it.Unless you're like me.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Well, I have to start this by saying I got the game for free and I still feel cheated.After playing through the Galactic War mode a couple of times I feel really sorry for whomever decided to spend actual money on this.The AI is horrible and the only way to meet any resistance when you're playing is to crank the difficulty up so high that it's got 4x as many resources as you.The entire speed of the game feels really slow and clunky. The graphics of the game are its worst point. It looks like something straight of ♥♥♥♥ing LEGO and pretty much 90% of the projectiles look like my units are shooting ♥♥♥♥ing BB pellets. I have it on the highest settings, so I doubt it can be any better.The amount of units is rather limited and progresses by tech tiers similarly to how the first Supreme Commander used to work, but it really feels limited in the amount of units there are and what they do. As far as I know, the only difference between fighting or using different factions is just the colour scheme. Nice.It feels like what Supreme Commander's spiritual sequel would've been if the developers had given up 2 hours into development and just wanted to finish it as soon as possible, but even with all the whining fanboys do around Supreme Commander 2 not being an exact copy of the original, I have to say that even with the severely limited amount of maps and single player missions, that game completely ANNIHILATES (get it?) this game in every aspect.Oh and there's skins for 5-10€ each to change how your commander looks, most of which are♥♥♥♥♥♥Let's not forget it's so poorly optimized that even running 2 clients of Minecraft and a server with a 300-mod unstable modpack, while playing Dota 2 in the background, slows my gaming computer less than this game with a browser open.DO NOT BUY.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												At first I was skeptical if I should buy the game or not, because of a lot of bad reviews here on Steam. When it was discounted, I took the chance and got it for quite a low price.After playing a few hours I am able to say that it's way better than I expected!It has great mechanisms to keep track over the ton of action that is going on in this game. Unfortunately there is no tutorial which teaches you to use these mechanisms, so you got to learn em yourself.To keep this short I will just sum this up in a simple list:Pro:+ Great graphics especially on high resolution screens+ Good mechanisms to keep track of the tons of units you will command+ Pretty simple resource system, so that's sorta easy to get into+ Great new approach to the RTS genre with orbiting planets+ Contains an easy to use level editor+ Has bots of different difficulty+ Has randomly generated campaign+ Very cheap on sales+ Superb classic soundtrackCons:- If not bought on sale might be a little too pricy- Loading a big solar system might take a while, because the planets are randomly generated each matchWell that's all.I really am enjoying this game and if you are a fan of the RTS genre you will likely too!

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												Great game, 9/10, definitely worth the money. Really fun action packed RTS game unlike no other. I have noticed a lot of bad reviews but 95% of bad things I have read about the game have been fixed in recent updates (such as the save game feature). The game is constantly being updated with bug fixes and other changes.Single player is fun and challenging -> in galactic war you start with basically nothing but as you take over planets in the galaxy you find upgrades. You can also play skirmish against the AI which can be fun and challenging especially for beginners. Online you can play 1v1 ranked matches or play custom matches where you can play massive FFA or team games and just about anything else you want with whoever you want. The game is made to be easily modded so there are a lot of mods that are really easy to download. You can even get mods that just about change the entire way the game is played. You can also download and play on planets other people have made or make your own planet(s).There are still a few small annoying bugs in the game, it often crashes and it helps to have a good PC but these are not major problems. I’m not playing on a very good PC so I can’t play games with more than about 3 planets but that doesn't make the game less fun and it is very easy to avoid games with a lot of planets. You can smash planets together and build death stars. What else could you possibly want in a game? Massive battles across a solar system? Great balance and gameplay? Well you have these things too and much more. :)

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Edit: I got this game when it was $50, and now I'm seeing the price it's currently being sold at.  Get the damn game.This game is very frustrating, decently unbalanced, and has a steep learning curve.  However, the concept is phenominal. Being a huge RTS fan, this has to be one RTS game that truly stands out to me.  It looks beautiful and I'd say it's revolutionary as far as gameplay mechanics.The game isn't finished.  It still needs a lot of work in it's current state.  I was surprised to find that it's in a released version and not still in beta after playing for a bit.  Despite the game being nowhere close to finished, it's on the right track.The only problems tha stand out to me are the balancing issues and lack of variety.  Different units for different factions would be sweet - like in C&C.  Every match seems to be a spam fest with who can send more bots to the other base first.  Defensive towers can't do much against a wave of 200 bots. (But, it DOES look pretty damn cool.)Aside from the game being somewhat buggy and unbalanced, I have hope in it.  Stretching gameplay onto multiple planets and even adding an orbital layer makes for a great concept.  The game needs to be developed further so the it can be truly fleshed out to it's full potential.With the minor faults aside, this a game is a good time. Definely a slow start with getting used to how everything works, but it's worth it in the long run.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												BEWARE... DRM DROPS THE GAME IN SINGLE PLAYER MODE.Total annihalation this is not... although you can tell it is trying to be it. I can see how this game could be fun... the idea is great and they have streamlined the units to remove a lot of the useless teirs that was found in Supreme Commander. It is also easy to tell that they intended for wars to be quick and only last around 30 minutes or so. I was playing against the AI on extreme mode (1 level above hard but not on master mode which is supposed to be slightly harder) and i was able to have 6 nukes going within 15 minutes (among other countless units) and won the game before 20 minutes (this was an example of me turtling). Just to warn you, if you are a quick strategy gamer, this game is really easy (at least against AI). When i ran a series of power play tests, the hard AI's didn't even come close to providing a challenge (i didn't try against master AI because i got bored). I simply spammed level one factories, ground units (tanks and some AA trucks) and teir 1 power plants/ metal extractors and charged the commander with around 50 units or so. BOOOOOOM. I just put up some turrets and SAMS around my base  to prevent the AI planes and pathetic death squads and I always win within 10-15 minutes.BUT...This game does not feel finished even though it has been released. I deliberately didn't install this game until the release because i knew the bugs would ruin it. I have encountered crashes to the desktop, strange graphical artifacts, the instructions given to units are not always followed (individual units do not always move/fire when told. Build orders are not always followed even when their is plenty of space for the building, even when the build order is queued) and the most annoying thing: SERVER CONNECTION LOSS CAUSES THE DRM TO DROP THE GAME... EVEN IN SINGLE PLAYER MODE. I will admit that the DRM really did cause me to rage quit the application... although i did go back to the game the next day and spent a few hours in it without any DRM issues (most likely because my connection didn't hicup).I have really tried to get into the game because i love these type of games usually. The trouble is, this just feels... crap. The graphics make the game feel like it should be run of a tablet computer, not a hardcore PC. I know that their are a lot of physics calculations going on and that these take priority over graphics but why are the textures so awful. I will admit that I did chuckle when my nuke missile launched and then flew around my planet backwards, I'm taking that as  compensation for the frustration i encounted when i had to order it to fire around 6 times before it fired. I also have a major problem with the fact that the blueprint snapping breaks constantly so that thet base building feels like a constant battle with the UI (yes I like my bases to look nice sometimes).If this game had remained in Beta status, i would forgive it... but it has been launched in a state which isn't fit for purpose so i have uninstalled it and am now leaving this review to warn others... I believe it could eventually be good... after about another years worth of development... but i don't recommend it in it's current state and do not support this level of DRM out of principle.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Planetary Annihilation is a giant, half baked, cluster♥♥♥♥ that fails to deliver on the promise of its predecessors and is a slap in the face to all the people who funded it through Kickstarter.Uber entertainment seems to be run by the marketing department, asking itself the question, "How do I make a game go viral?" instead of asking, "How do I make a good game that will go viral?" There's livestreaming integration via Twitch along with ample controls to shoutcast and record matches, and the ability to add extensions and mods, but the core parts of game are severely under developed.Planetary Annihilation has failed the basics. For instance, rebinding a key shows a developer error message. Commanders will spawn sometimes extremely close to each other. Pathfinding is poor. There's no option to save Multiplayer games, and practically speaking, there's no instructions. The only "tutorial" is an old YouTube video that's sounds like an advertisement and is so basic it won't be of use to anyone. It is so bad even the dwindling community has expressed creating an extension themselves to add tips into the game.Speaking of the community, less than three weeks after its release there are only a handful of multiplayer matches and PA's price has dropped significantly on steam, both of which are indicators that this is a failure of a game. Outside of the game Uber hasn't even provided things like stats, or tech trees, and the poor suckers who bought the game for full price are expected to add that knowledge to the Internet themselves.This ties into the biggest problem: usability. PA takes place in a solar system where you can hop planets, but the planets are tiny King Kai planets, so you can only see half of your planet at a time like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ fog of war. There is a picture-in-picture mode, but not dual monitor support. The lack of tips means that after several games, many of us people didn't even know what planet they were on, much less how to get off it and launch an invasion. When you run into an army, the name of the person to whom it belongs isn't even shown. I couldn't figure out how teleporters worked until someone told me several matches later, and figuring out how nukes works is an exercise in random clicking. I landed on a planet, I think it was a gas planet, which means I can mine it? I don't know.This is coming from someone who has played both Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander/2 and was willing to buy Planetary Annihilation on pedigree alone.Usability is super important when there is a lot going on and there is more going on in PA than ever. PA builds on its predecessors main tech trees of Vehicle, Naval, Bots, and Air with a third (fifth?) dimension of Orbital and the inclusion of different planets on which to wage war. A (real, not space) Navy seems kind of useless on tiny King Kai planets, and the purpose of bots still overlaps with vehicles. Not that I was expecting a TA/SupCom/2/PA game to get rid of bots, but that Kickstarter stretch goal to include Naval units? Bad idea and worse implementation.Games are enormous and sprawling, with hundreds of units and structures. Zooming out reduces the units to icons, which are another failed attempt to fix the problem. They glitchly overlap, and look the same. If you were designing an UI to move icons around, you'd probably at least make them different colors.While most of the time you're watching little icons come into, and blink out of existence, it's not like you'd actually enjoy the graphics anyway. There's only one faction in PA, and all the units look like toys. And I mean the type of toys you give to toddlers; the designs are generic and strangely clean for weapons of war. I'm not expecting Warhammer 40k levels of grit, but the unit designs look like something a Freshman graphics student would turn in for solid B. The Supreme Commander 2 units looked more detailed and just... better.To be fair, there are some innovative selection features: highlighting an area will only select combat units and not builder units, you can click and drag areas to have fabricators build a lot of things, and... well that's all I've discovered after reading up all I could on the Internet and playing.When all this is tied to the underhanded fact that Uber sold this game in stores for full price while still in "Early Access" (which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t because if anybody can access it then it's not "early") and the fact that there's expensive DLC already, I can only feel sorry for the the people duped into Kickstarting Uber's salaries.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I dont usually write reviews for games, but i felt like i had to say something here.I had been following this game off and on since it was on Kickstarter, it sounded like a great idea in a genre that seems stale.I held off on getting involved with the game during Alpha and Beta, because too many times i have had my impression of a game ruined by getting involved in the early access.So I noticed that the game had officially released! and the price tag was down from that rediculous 60$ sum.So being a strategy fan i decided to go get PA and enjoy the finished product.Well it hits you pretty early on as your playing, that this game isnt finished. IT is missing textures and animations, not to mention the different commanders have no difference between them ( just the skins really). The Single player seemed to lack any real strategy, seeing who could churn out more units faster. Oh, and it lags and i dont mean graphics lag. There is no offline single player,  so you have to be connected to the servers ALWAYS and if the connnection goes bad which it seemed to, then the game will lag even if just with the computer.This game has left me with the same feeling i get when I buy an early access game, it is not complete and i feel it is dishonest practice to describe it as a full release when clearly it is missing so much.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Summary: Dont buy. Greedy devs. Kickstarter cashout after butthurt because their second kickstarter flopped.From my comments on the latet "Titan" release, which should have been a free expansion to this:So let me get this straight, I paid $60 dollars for a game you are now packaging into a "DLC/Expansion" that costs $40 dollars and the game STILL feels unfinished, uninspired, and poorly designed from the ground up? And no mod suppourt? Way to make the consumer feel like we got cheated. Sorry nobody wanted to crowdfund your other game and you now packaged its ideas into this one, but poor business move. I will not be purchasing and I will be avoiding any project you associate with. You should fire whoever had the idea of this. Everyone that paid full price should be given a copy of this. If you called it a "Free Expansion" like the guys who make the Endless series of games, you would see sales flourish again.Original review followsfurther♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off customer note: Now its on sale for SEVEN BUCKS? when you hosed everyone for a brutally unfinished product that they bought on good faith and now you reduce it to CLEARANCE price? way to spit in our faces further for our purchase of this horrid piece of garbage. back to Starcraft II2015 notes: They are still adding units like a unit cannon and submarines... If you game was done you would not be adding entire CLASSES of units. Fail.New reviewNow that gameplay has been fleshed out, and technical issues like offline play have been solved, looking at the core game I am still dissappointed. There are many who might cite my reasons as positive for the game, but I am not a fan of the end result. Recently was on sale for like 5$. I feel very cheated by this Early Acess title that is "Final Release" and "Full Feature"-ProsLarge scale multiple planet combatSound is good, even if it does lack that 'oomph' of games with a camera that is closer up.Music is good, although limited.Multiplayer works well enough, and is (As of oct. 2014) populated enough to find a game easily.Everything works very smoothly, from worker and unit AI to menus and UI-ConsEconomy would be good, but maps are so random you could get a spawn point with zero resources, or ten, which can end a game before it starts (Patch is coming for symmetry I am told... )Combat is very bland due to replacable units and the feeling of no impact of losing one. (Not like losing your first tank in Company of heroes, or that ever important first couple units in Starcraft.Sound is good as I said above, but you will get very sick of the same four tracks of music, and I like a little variance in my explosion sounds if theres gonna be 50 of the same unit dying. personal taste makes this a con.The tech tree is very uninspired. You have a few types of units (Bots[Infantry], Air, Naval, Vehicles, Orbital) and two tiers of those units, you make a basic and an advanced production building and suppourt/defensive structures.Units themselves are very boring. Instead of having some standard units with some specialists and some power units, you have units that are only good at one role, or are bad at multiple, and nothing that really *Shines* except for maybe the orbital lasers and the planets-as-weapons thing. Snooze.The campaign is absolutely HORRID, it is a "randomly generated galaxy" which is really just a series of skirmishes in an attempt to make it seem like an epic space campaign. Not even worth mentioning it HAS single player as far as i'm concerned. Limits rather than expands the tech tree to make an inventory system, much fail.Balance is very, very wrong. Defenses dont take more than a few hits and take ages to kill anything, tons of units one-shot and are one-shotted, its eseentially a race to the superweapons or spam so much until you can whittle down the commander. makes for very boring gameplay.

number of helpful: 46 of 87 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Looking for the next big thing in RTS’?  Look no further.  This game revolutionizes the RTS genre.  Instead of square maps you have spherical ones.  No longer can you get in a corner and only worry about two directions.  People can attack from all 360 degrees of your base.  Most RTS have one map per game.  In PA battle grounds are actual one to many planets in a solar system.  The size of the game is staggering.  There are a lot of different kinds of units.  There are vehicles, bots, air, naval, and orbital.  There are nukes, HUGH engines you can use to smash one planet into another, and metal planets can basically be turned into death stars.  On top of all of this you have procedurally generated solar systems and planets as well as a built in system designer for creating your own planets and solar systems.  The objective of the game is to kill the other opponent(s) commander(s).  If your commander is killed then you lose.  So just as in chess you must keep him protected.  Early game he is a powerful unit, late game he is a liability.Single player.  Know first that this game started as a multiplayer that got single player features added in.  You basically have two options.  AI Skirmish and Galactic War. AI Skirmish in which you fight it out against one or more AIs, all of which can be adjust for difficulty level.  Galactic War is a randomly generated galaxy that you can adjust the size of at the start of the game.  You take your commander and hop from system to system and try to conquer the whole galaxy.  Die and it is over.  No two play throughs will ever be the same.Multiplayer. Up to 10 players currently (this will be increase with future updates) can duke it out over a solar system.  You can do FFA or team games.  With FFA there are options to have dynamic alliances where you can basically on the whim in the game team up and backstab your other opponents. With Team games you can share armies and economies or simply a team for victory.Future Updates.  We expect there to be a lot of competitive things like match making and ladders to be added in as well as the number of players increase.  We also expect Galactic war will be made possible for multiplayer for clan wars.  The devs have made it clear that they mean to keep supporting by creating updates for a long time.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												This game is pure awesome. I don't care about how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the devs are. It doesn't make the game any less fun when I play it.As a person who was unfamiliar with the RTS genre, this was a perfect game to get started on. I picked it up for free from BundleStars, and this is by far the best game I've recieved in a giveaway.At first the game seemed confusing for me. There was no proper tutorial and the fact that I'm new to RTSes just makes this more so, but in my first game I already picked up the controls real fast - it was all very intinuitive. It also is really tactical, which I'm sure skill will make a big difference when playing against harder AIs or people. As far I can see, there isn't that much of a "meta" which means you can freely develop your own playstyle while still being effective. The game also runs fairly smooth (at least on PC). I've not experienced as much as an FPS drop yet. Finally, the amount of flaws is minimal for an early access game. The only bad thing I've encountered so far is the fact that there's no tutorial - as I mentioned above. Game progress can also be slow (games take around half an hour or more), which I'm sure some people DO mind, despite being able to save the game.I encourage people to pick up this game, it definitely isn't overpriced and to play it if you happen to recieve it for free like me.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												This game rides along the border of me liking it and hating it. Planetary Annihilation, to me, feels like the groundwork for the perfect game. Let me list some pros and cons and you'll see what I mean.The Good- You can smash planets together!- You can use a Deathstar-like planet to blow up other planets with a laser beam!- You can design your own systems with plenty of collision and laser-ready planets- Many different ways of attacking and defending. From land units, naval, air units, orbital, and nuclear, it becomes very interesting to try and tear a hole through someone's defenses. When you're dealing with multiple planets, things can fall out of your favor by overlooking a certain defense, but the same thing can apply for your enemies.The Bad- THE LAG!!! Anyone who has touched this game will know that it eats at computer memory like a homeless monkey in a banana store. On top of it not being optimized graphically, there is currently no such thing as a true single-player game. All games, even if you are playing by yourself, are hosted on one of three different servers throughout the world. This leads to some ridiculous load times, and tons of latency while playing the game.- Bare-bones tech. Tier 1 and Tier 2 buildings and units. That's it. On top of that, there are no different races. Everyone has access to the exact same units and technology, which is unheard of in the RTS market. Somehow there is enough diversity that games are still fun, but I can't even imagine how much more amazing this game could be with some variation.Overall, I would recommend purchasing this game, but do it when it's on sale, like I did. The game is fun but feels incomplete. Don't pay full price.

number of helpful: 30 of 56 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												The scope of this game was so promising I decided to purchase it soley based on that. I can't recommend this game because it STILL isnt a finished product writing this in October 2014.  Luckily I have a gaming PC, with a lot of expensive hardware, but I feel that typically most systems will not be able to run this game smoothly because of the poor utilization in-game. It is RAM extensive and CPU extensive as-well. There was a point in-time where the Devs were motivated and updating the game, now it seems they have lost that motivation and are packing up and moving on to the next game. In essence they've abandoned this game, I don't see this game ever meeting it's potential either. One of the concepts of this game is traveling the galaxy and expanding, there are no space battles on the galaxy map, only fixed movement trails when you send spacecraft to other planets. Another concept is the borderless strategy at play, it isn't a conventional RTS where the map is flat, you play on a spherical world, there are pros and cons to this, but I find that it is too poorly utilized and needs to be worked on. For example for people who like to turtle or play defensively it is impossible to build an adequate defense because of the spherical world, they need to encourage defensive type gameplay as-well and not just one type of gameplay. I think that they need to make the spherical worlds larger so the gameplay is more flatter like a convential RTS however once you run off the the screen you can move around the planet freely in the spherical concept they have already integrated. So it will have a conventional RTS feel, but also incorperate the spherical concept as-well to make a outstanding RTS game. Pros:It's an RTS gameMultiplayer BasedLarge Scale BattlesCon:Can't fight in outerspaceCan't Micro Very Well In This Game Compared To Conventional RTS Games Campaign? Should I even call it that... Small community due to game being rubbishGUI experience is like groping a pineapple.Graphics, Unit Modeling, was drawn up and conceived by a pre-school class.This game will genuinely dissapoint you upon buying it. They really flaunt the scope of the game but it is so poorly utilized they might as well have not incorperated it in the first place.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												To the majority of the negative reviewers:Get over yourselves.Seriously, start acting your own age.Rarely in the reviews for PA do I ever see anything praising the actual gameplay.What??? A review that talks about the actual game itself and not the financial dealings of the company?To be fair in this review, I'll do a pros/cons list so all the little children can migrate down below to the cons section...Pros:- It's very smooth. I'm talking both gameplay and textures. I love the "blocky" feel to the game. - Lasers. C'mon guys, you can build a freakin death star in this game. How could you hate on the death star?- Halleys. Ok, you probably don't know what the halleys are if you don't play PA. Basically, they're giant thrusters you put on planets to make them fly into eaechother. - Little tiny worker robots. These things are adorable. Like actually. I use them cause the sound effect they make sounds like little children happily doing manual labor at your whim.- It feels finished. There's no open ended "coming soon" bs. It's a solid standalone game. Here's where the haters come in. "TITANS WAS A RIPOFF OMG KYS UBER".Ok, well, yes it was kinda dumb for them to release Titans as another standalone game. HOWEVER! Did you children do your homework? No? Why am I not surprised.If you had done your research or just happened to be around at the time Titans was released, Uber actually pulled PA from the steam store and put Titans in it's stead. Titans took over the original cost and that was that. But all the little children couldn't put 2 and 2 together, so they all assumed they were being scammed.Maybe if the children stopped hating on Uber for a second, they'd see a possible strategy. Consider that it's possible that Uber wanted to release Titans into the game but put it as their face for the game itself? Yes it backfired which is why it's back as more of a DLC than anything. But still, stop hating on the game...Ok, and the cons:- I am on an iMac, on which it runs beautifully 99% of the time. It's crashed twice, mainly when then enemy AI spawns in too many units. I tried to replicate the crash using my own units, so I manufactured 5000+ units, during which my framerate dropped a little but it stayed up. I haven't heard of it crashing on PC.- It can get a bit repetitive if you don't have friends to play it with.- The imbecilic reviewers in the "Negative" section. Remove them and we can all forget about the minor issues above.So yeah. 10/10, IGN something, idk. Go buy the ♥♥♥♥ing game.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								The absolute scale of what Planetary annihilation is doing is quite astounding. Have interplanetary duels with nukes or send heaps of moon rocks to completely annihilate their planet. Unit cap is 10,000 units. "wait what!?" is probably what you are thinking and yes you can have a max of 10.000...per PLAYER! :O. That is a 10x improvement over supreme commanders unit cap and that game had enormous battles. Unfortunately there are shortcomings that can overshadow the amazing feats Planetary Annihilation is boasting. The game can crawl to a complete stop on loading planets, watch your fps drop dramatically every now and again, A.I is horrendous if you start on another planet and they can't reach you, your commander may glitch and get stuck depending on the planets geometry (for example stuck on a corner of a hill/mountain etc) and lastly for me I feel as though strategic missiles have lost their destructive capabilities that they had in suppreme commander and now are just miniscule dust clouds that do absoultely nothing to the enemy.Despite these flaws Planetary Annihilation is still in gamma stage and I have faith in uber entertainment to address these issues and are already doing a superb job at fixing issues. When I first heard about this game I had my doubts that it could be done . On the other hand upon playing it and finally having the chance to experience large scale battles on a unprecedented scale in the Rts genre I have to say congratulations to the developers that made my dream Rts game a reality. Here's hoping that the issues get addressed as they are small blemishes on an otherwise prodigious planetary game.If you loved supreme comander forged alliance then you will love Planetary Annihilation. 9/10.

Early Access Review
								The game has potential, but the controls are odd and the battle happens in a multi-dimensional matrix. The engineering bots don't help building and repairing stuff while you are fighting.  So you get crushed by the computer that acts like 3 or 4 players against you: building economy, building factories and organizing attacks by multiple fronts: 2 ground flanks, air squadrons and orbital ships all at once.After playing this game you end up exhausted instead of relaxed. I never finished a game, I got tired and overwhelmed by micro-managing more task that I could handle. This game is like getting in the cockpit of an Air-bus A380 without crew, in mid-air, with all the alarm buttons beeping and blinking all at once... LOL The game would be fun if you could assign officers to take care of certain tasks like: (i) a support lieutenant to take care of the mining, repairing and buildings; (ii) a general that could take care of the ground; (iii) an admiral for the sea; and (iv) a sky marshal for orbital defense (your choice of how many), so you can take care of those tasks you feel doing that day and make it a fair fight, but above all, fun and stress free.

content:

												Are you looking for the next best thing in RTS gaming? Are you hoping for modern and extended version of Supreme Commander?Then look somewhere else.The Good:- Clean and concise Art style that doesn't really get old.The Bad:- Unoptimised beyond belief, even if you have a rig that smashes the games recommended requirements, it runs poorly and suffers from extreme slowdown in mid-late game.- The 'orbital layer' feels awfully tacked on and lacks any strategic depth outside of blanketing your planet with orbital fighters.- Gamechanging Bugs that have existed since the game became available to the public still remain. Certain units remain broken beyond belief even after months of constructive criticism from testers.- No Offline Mode.- Only one faction.I regret paying for this game.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												As a once avid Total Annihilation then SupCom player, this game as it stands is a disappointment. While the game is now a '3D planet' the gameplay is unmistakably 2D and unlike many old maps there's no real bottlenecks or impassable terrain beyond random water placement or small jutting pieces of rock. There is literally no challenge from the AI and near zero meaning to your own base: just spamming factories; no defensive lines or support structures really: everything is liquid (which could be good) but nothing has customisation or choice like SupCom's tech or upgrading mechanics. I imagine it's an alright game multiplayer but it is truly lacking depth in comparison to SupCom with respect to it's abysmal 'campaign/adventure' mode, it's current AI's strategies and outrageously fickle gameplay.I have tried it at multiple stages of the beta but only managed 55 minutes of interest for a £20 game. For someone who wants to enjoy this as mostly a singleplayer game it is nothing in comparison to SupCom or TA. There just seems to be a lack of fun in it since you effectively do the same thing each game with the lack of factions, tech or experimentals. The only unique thing about the game is commanding relatively unresourceful moons to crash but in reality this is just another form of a nuke and is not half as important as 10 factories.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												The main reason i give this game a "recommed" is because think of this game as a steriotypical american's dream. Explosions, robots, death, robot gore and more explosions because logic! my main quarrel with this game is that you have to have a "beefy computer" in order to not lag as much. When my friend and i attempted playing i ended up crashing his computer forcing a restart of the game/steam. my other problem with the game is that there is way too much to manage when by yourself seeing how you can make infinite troops. (i dont multi-task very well) thats the main reason i play with my friend as it becomes easier to manage your faction with the share army button. An entire match is basically "zerg rush and hope you win" there is some strategy and some counters but very minimal overall. The galactic war seems a bit rigged seeing how you hope to get an AI buddy or a good peice of technology, nope its randomly generated. it would be nice to find two technologies on one planet and choose one of the two instead of a randomly generated technology machine as in some matches in the galactic war seem rigged as your AI enemy gets all the technology (effectivly cheating with nuclear weapons) while if you dont have anything to counter super weapons its GG from beggining. This list could go on forever, but now to what this game does right.This game manages to be addicting to come back to even after excruciating losses. The planet creator is a great idea as you can make custom maps for your friends. When i mentioned in the very beggining about the steriotypical american's dream. That means what it sounds like. Constant explosions, lasers everywhere, and a deathstar(esk) annihilaser that makes planets go boom! The concept is very interesting and with the lore's setup it seems primed for a story than just hey you hate these guys kill them. It is extremely fun to see that you can travel between planets and colonize them before your enemies. Then dominate them. Again this list could go on too so here is my rating for this game. But otherwise this is a crap game.5/10

number of helpful: 22 of 41 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												The first thing I would like to point out the always online DRM is a pain.  Whilst it is quicker to connect to Uber’s servers than it was before it is still quite slow.  Even setting up a single player skirmish or a joining a battle in Galactic conquest takes time on top of the log in DRM.   My steam tells me that I have 21 hours in game, although I disagree, It is more likely to be 5 + hours of me trying to get past the Login in DRM and then another hour of me trying to get past other loading screens.The game is also rather difficult to pick up an still lacks  a proper tutorial and there is a lot of features thrown in your face.  The best way to learn how to play is to play the galactic war because that way you can take it step by step.However the game does have some great systems and mechanics, and so many of the units/building are really nice.  The naval units are really well designed, although I they are not as used as much as I would like.  The Gas giants are a really call concept, and the wide variety of units is really good.  The AI can be tricky to beat at first because of its ability to multitask but once you know what to do the AI is beatable.  On the whole the gameplay is solid and quite enjoyable.Aesthetically the game isn’t the prettiest game but it isn’t ugly and the graphics work this sort of game so it is fine.  On the other hand the full orchestral sound track is great, and it really suits the game.If you buy the game make sure you have a reliable internet connection and don’t have to worry about 3rd party fire walls.  If you want an epic sic-fi RTS, then this game is for you, just make sure you understand the game is heavily affected by always online DRM, still has a couple of bugs, and that the game can be quite crashy.  And be prepared to wait to get past loading screens.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												I look forward to playing it when they REALLY do finish it.It looks like it will be a fun game. I really love RTS games, and this one gives me the impression that it will be superb. The problem is, I just won't play a game that isn't finished, and this one clearly isn't.Take this for example. I try to play it on my super powerful computer, and the screen flashes like crazy. It doesn't flicker, it flashes from pitch black to normal screen, and repeat. Turns out this is an error with the game and NVidia, so I'm forced to play it on my less powerful machine.So seeing as I had just sat through the intro video, I click the mouse so that I can skip it. It doesn't skip it, forcing me to watch it a second time, but I suddenly hear people talking in the background. It turns out that what appears to be a YouTube video is overlayed in the background, and my clicking suddenly started it playing, so I'm listening to the developers chatting about their game!I check out the tutorials, expecting to see one in which you play along, and it teaches you as you go, but instead a video appears, with the most annoying voice over man ever explaining it. I'm not in the mood to listen to someone repeat how "amazing" and "incredible" the game is, as well as try to absorb and remember everything at once, so I skip it. I've played dozens of hours of Supreme Commander, so how hard can this game be?I click on single player, and start the galactic war. Pick a planet to do battle on, and I'm in the game. I'm off running around, building things, finding it odd that when you click and drag turrets, the gap is massive (in SupCom you could connect one to another), when suddenly a voice tells me I need more energy storage.This is where I get fed up. I have no energy storage buildings. I assume I have to unlock them in Galactic mode, but if that's a very odd thing to limit you on. I'm on one planet, the AI is on another, so I assume I need to build some kind of flying unit, but I'm limited to land and boat. I then try out the teleporter building, but can't use it, so I build another one thinking it's a point to point building, but that doesn't work either.After 15 minutes to aimless clicking, I eventually tab out to go look at a tutorial, and all I can find are videos of the beta, which look very different to what I'm playing, so I switch back to the game, which is now running at a snails pace. I get bored, quit the game, and suddenly my machine is also running at the same slow pace, resulting in me holding down the power button to turn it off.It's not the PC, I should add. I can play all sorts of games on max, and the new Wolfenstein on High.The game WILL be good... but they should not have considered it finished just yet.You can't save during skirmish games, and you need to sign up and log in to play. There is NO offline mode, it seems!I'll play it when it's finished.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even in its early state, this game is oozing with class and style. A throwback to the olden days of Command & Conquer, Planetary Annihilation takes Real-Time Strategy and adds Space Colonisation into the mix. This game seems to have it all, great graphics, a good combat system and a really innovative way of winning, via flinging moons at your opponent. As a wise man once said, "There's no such thing as overkill, just Fire and Reload"There are a few issues I have with this game that any potential buyer should consider before purchasing:1. It's still in Beta - While most of the Alpha-stage bugs have been ironned out; there are still many Beta bugs hidden in the woodwork; so your experiences may vary.2. AI is a little overpowered - This might not seem like much, but the AI is structured so that if you beat it, the next time you get a harder AI and, while it's nice, it really doesn't have a way to make the AI less difficult again. (You can reduce the AI's resource collecting, but that's not really the same)3. It's over priced - All's fair in love and war, except the insane price tag. You know what other games cost me this much? Sim City 5 and Red Alert 3. Both of these really weren't worth forking out the cash for it. Neither's this game right now. If you can get it for less, say in a Steam Sale, go for it, it's well worth it.
