number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												Updating an out of date Review:This is honestly my favorite game of all time. Ever. It combines everything I want to see in a game into, well, a game. Specifically one I like. But for some reason, not EVERYONE shares my views on EVERYTHING ( I know, weird, right?), so here is a compilation of why PA is awesome, and the problems it still has.PA has no unit cap. None at all. You can build 4000 factories and with those factories infinitely spam out units if you so wanted, and the game would not stop you. In fact, the only thing standing in your way, is either:a) your computerb) your internetc) the server you just killed by building over 10000 units and trying to get them to do something.PA (now) has singleplayer offline mode. Yes, you can play offline now. The only problem is you need a rig that meets the reccommended requirements to get a reasonable experience.PA has interplanetary warfare and interaction. Ever wanted to fling a planet at someone? Well now you can. There are litterally no downsides here.PA is incredibly moddable. You can make whole new units/balances/metas/UIs/Biomes for PA. Once again, no downsides.PA is a macro-oriented game. It's more about base-building and army management than click-spammy micro where whoever clicks the best and fastest wins. In PA, you need to be good at strategy, assess your opponent's weaknesses before he discovers yours and strike from an unexpected side, or two sides, or from space. If you love SC2 because of its micro and want something similar in all your RTS games, this isn't really the game you're looking for.PA has a somewhat steep learning curve, unless you've played similar games before. (TA, SupCom, SupCom FA, etc.) It also has effectively no tutorial, so you need to play for a few hours (preferably against a freind, the AI is pretty mean to new players) before you start understanding what's going on. After that, it is a highly enjoyable game.PA has a competetive ranked system (just implemented) it's a fun way to prove yourself against others! Not as fleshed out as it could be, but we're looking forward to more improvements in the coming months. Also, if more players played ranked, we'd have a better ranked system simply due to population density.PA's Devs are highly invested in the game and are constantly talking with the community on their forums. PA has a great community, and great community-dev interaction (I think we can all thank Jables for this!).All in all, I'd give this game an 8.5/10. Yeah that's right, my favorite game of all time got a 8.5 out of 10, even I can see that there are issues with it. Although it's a little buggy at times (mostly if your drivers are out of date), it's not completely balanced yet, and the UI in some cases could use a decent bit of work, it is the only game I own where I consistently come back to it week after week and constantly take part in the community. I would highly reccomend this game if you are into this kind of RTS.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2013
Early Access Review
								(Please note this was written during the games extremely early Alpha Stage, All is subject to change)Basicaly it is a very rudimentary version of Supreme Commander. The resource system is the same, You start with a commanding robot (who if dies you lose the game and also sets off a nuclear explosion around him) and build Mass Generators and Energy Generators and try to have more Generators outputting than what your builders are using for input.It plays in much of the same way as well in that you build Factories (Land, Air, Sea, Robot) and pump out as many units as possible, each of these buildings also has 3 tiers with different units like supreme commander.Unlike supreme commander though they manage to do it simply and effectively. I personally had a hard time tackling supreme commander and how to play it correctly and still do to this day. In this game however, it manages to stay fun in the same way of supreme commander without being as complicated.Unfortunetly the space aspect is not ingame yet, which is what i am looking forward to. You can currently zoom out of the planet and see the solar system, but you are not able to build space faring structures yet. You can also zoom out further to a grid that is HUGE, currently it only shows the planet and the sun on it, with all of your current unit cards plopped in the sun. Which leads me to believe there will be multiple stars with planets in the full game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even in its early state, this game is oozing with class and style. A throwback to the olden days of Command & Conquer, Planetary Annihilation takes Real-Time Strategy and adds Space Colonisation into the mix. This game seems to have it all, great graphics, a good combat system and a really innovative way of winning, via flinging moons at your opponent. As a wise man once said, "There's no such thing as overkill, just Fire and Reload"There are a few issues I have with this game that any potential buyer should consider before purchasing:1. It's still in Beta - While most of the Alpha-stage bugs have been ironned out; there are still many Beta bugs hidden in the woodwork; so your experiences may vary.2. AI is a little overpowered - This might not seem like much, but the AI is structured so that if you beat it, the next time you get a harder AI and, while it's nice, it really doesn't have a way to make the AI less difficult again. (You can reduce the AI's resource collecting, but that's not really the same)3. It's over priced - All's fair in love and war, except the insane price tag. You know what other games cost me this much? Sim City 5 and Red Alert 3. Both of these really weren't worth forking out the cash for it. Neither's this game right now. If you can get it for less, say in a Steam Sale, go for it, it's well worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												Updating an out of date Review:This is honestly my favorite game of all time. Ever. It combines everything I want to see in a game into, well, a game. Specifically one I like. But for some reason, not EVERYONE shares my views on EVERYTHING ( I know, weird, right?), so here is a compilation of why PA is awesome, and the problems it still has.PA has no unit cap. None at all. You can build 4000 factories and with those factories infinitely spam out units if you so wanted, and the game would not stop you. In fact, the only thing standing in your way, is either:a) your computerb) your internetc) the server you just killed by building over 10000 units and trying to get them to do something.PA (now) has singleplayer offline mode. Yes, you can play offline now. The only problem is you need a rig that meets the reccommended requirements to get a reasonable experience.PA has interplanetary warfare and interaction. Ever wanted to fling a planet at someone? Well now you can. There are litterally no downsides here.PA is incredibly moddable. You can make whole new units/balances/metas/UIs/Biomes for PA. Once again, no downsides.PA is a macro-oriented game. It's more about base-building and army management than click-spammy micro where whoever clicks the best and fastest wins. In PA, you need to be good at strategy, assess your opponent's weaknesses before he discovers yours and strike from an unexpected side, or two sides, or from space. If you love SC2 because of its micro and want something similar in all your RTS games, this isn't really the game you're looking for.PA has a somewhat steep learning curve, unless you've played similar games before. (TA, SupCom, SupCom FA, etc.) It also has effectively no tutorial, so you need to play for a few hours (preferably against a freind, the AI is pretty mean to new players) before you start understanding what's going on. After that, it is a highly enjoyable game.PA has a competetive ranked system (just implemented) it's a fun way to prove yourself against others! Not as fleshed out as it could be, but we're looking forward to more improvements in the coming months. Also, if more players played ranked, we'd have a better ranked system simply due to population density.PA's Devs are highly invested in the game and are constantly talking with the community on their forums. PA has a great community, and great community-dev interaction (I think we can all thank Jables for this!).All in all, I'd give this game an 8.5/10. Yeah that's right, my favorite game of all time got a 8.5 out of 10, even I can see that there are issues with it. Although it's a little buggy at times (mostly if your drivers are out of date), it's not completely balanced yet, and the UI in some cases could use a decent bit of work, it is the only game I own where I consistently come back to it week after week and constantly take part in the community. I would highly reccomend this game if you are into this kind of RTS.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2013
Early Access Review
								(Please note this was written during the games extremely early Alpha Stage, All is subject to change)Basicaly it is a very rudimentary version of Supreme Commander. The resource system is the same, You start with a commanding robot (who if dies you lose the game and also sets off a nuclear explosion around him) and build Mass Generators and Energy Generators and try to have more Generators outputting than what your builders are using for input.It plays in much of the same way as well in that you build Factories (Land, Air, Sea, Robot) and pump out as many units as possible, each of these buildings also has 3 tiers with different units like supreme commander.Unlike supreme commander though they manage to do it simply and effectively. I personally had a hard time tackling supreme commander and how to play it correctly and still do to this day. In this game however, it manages to stay fun in the same way of supreme commander without being as complicated.Unfortunetly the space aspect is not ingame yet, which is what i am looking forward to. You can currently zoom out of the planet and see the solar system, but you are not able to build space faring structures yet. You can also zoom out further to a grid that is HUGE, currently it only shows the planet and the sun on it, with all of your current unit cards plopped in the sun. Which leads me to believe there will be multiple stars with planets in the full game.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Преемница Total Annihilation вышла колоритной, емкой и легкой в освоении... Однако сложной в исполнении. Благодаря большой свободе действий и большом количестве построек и юнитов вы можете сыграть в РА сотню раз и каждый раз использовать разную стратегию. Пожертвовав одиночной компанией разработчики дали игрокам такую свободу действий, которой не было в любой другой стратегии в реальном времени:вы можете создать наимощнейший танковый парк или огромный флот, который окажет незаменимую поддержку при штурме укрепленной базы противника, а может оказаться так, что рандом выкинет "финт ушами" и планета будет полностью покрыта льдом и придется полагаться на сухопутные и воздушные войска и тому подобное, также в игре присутсвуют орудия массового поражения: от ядерных боеголовок до изменения орбиты естественного спутника планеты и обрушения всей этой мощи на менее развитого противника. Конечно же не обошлось и без минусов, начиная долгими загрузками локации и заканчивая вылетами игры. Также разработчики перестарались с игровым ИИ. Если на среднем уровне можно изловчиться и выйграть, то на самой высокой сложности вы еще не раз всплакнете над обломками своего командира. Если же учесть, что это еще недоработанная альфа-версия, то становится очевидно, какая игра станет стратегией года.

content:
Posted: April 25
												Don't jump on the hate train, this game is quite fun! It's a sequel to the classic Annihilation and plays like Supreme Commander on a much larger scale! In fact, scale is one of the main challenges of the game and if you can build up faster than your opponent, you will most likely win.Fighting over systems, and the planetary combat is awesome! This isn't something you find in other games and it's really under-appreciated. Due to the crowdfunding going way overboard, some players began trolling the community and created a hate train against the developers, but honestly I don't regret buying this game, and I'll probably buy the sequel as well. It's a lot of fun and absolutely gorgeous graphics!

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												from the start of this game, the gameplay was absolutely incredible. the AI is just awesome to battle against and the cartoony graphics add a nice touch. it's fun to team up with friends to battle mass hordes of nuke and tank spamming AI. Using planets to destroy other planets is so satifying as well. Also the variety of units is great. From sea to space it is trully amazing.The map creator was also wondeful. it is a bit tough at first when you can master it, you can make truly awesome maps. i have made with this creator a starwars galaxy map, a 'our solar system map' and a map that is a giant urban sprawl.there are a few issues with the game. a couple of said issues are that matches with a huge map count lag like crazy, having many AI in the late game starts to lag the map, some connection issues and there are no factions so no unique units. but these problems are minor and probably will be patched/added in future updates.In short I highly recommend this game for any stratergy gamer due to all these reasons.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Re-writing this review. I've backed and tested this game from Alpha for reference.The game itself is extremely fun with friends. The AI can provide a challenge too but at its heart you'll want to bring some friends along for the planet smashing fun. GENERAL:PA is an amazing game, both in gameplay and in visual representation. The ONLY limiting factor is your machines capability (And internet if you're playing with friends). If you have a high end PC you've built recently this game should run like a charm. The sheer amount of destruction that is unleash over the course of the game is astounding. If you can run a massive system with lots of moons/planets then you're in for a good time. The planets orbit around the star and each other, if you're close enough to another planet you can actually see your enemies buildings and units on the passing planet and if it's in your planets orbit you can send a welcome nuke their way!The gameplay is similar to Total Annihilation or Supreme Commander. Resources come in two fantastic flavours: Metal and Energy. Both of these are streamed from your resource producing structures and to be effecient you'll need a lot coming in to pump it back out into units and buildings. The combat is fun and engaging from early game scouting and raiding to mid game clashes and then end game battles. When you add other planets in you'll eventually be playing galactic marbles throwing around moons and asteroids. Units have purpose and balance. You have several types of units to choose from (Vehicles like tanks, rovers, AA. Then there is Bots which are your general raiders, snipers, artillery. There are also Naval units and Air units which are you bombers, scouts, air superioirity and long range bombardment) Your buildings and defense are also useful but the aim of the game is attack not turtle in and hope for the best. You have the ground layer which is where most of your attention will be, positioning, attacking, pulling a ruse, etc. There is also an orbital layer which supports your conquests and helps expand to new planets so you can then turn them into 'rocks with rockets'The UI is clear and concise which is exactly what you want in this kind of game. Resources are displayed up top. Unit actions on the right side of the screen, A mini screen which can also switch between several bookmarked locations is also present. Your building menu is displayed on the bottom of your screen when you click the apporpriate units. The lobbies received an overhaul several times. They are easy to read and navigate. It shouldn't be hard to find a game with your friends or create one yourself. Once you do find a game you can easily customize which colour/commander/team you want to be on. You can also set how many teams there are, whether players will share armies and what resource rates will be.During this time the game will load the system (there will be an icon indicating this) As the game begins your planet choice will be available. A system generator is present. This lets you set up a 'map' which your computer can handle (the defaults generally contain 2-4 planets depending on your roll) There are also some set maps by the Devs which vary in size. The generator is easy to use and fiddle around with and helps you test your computers performance with the orbital bodies 'simulated' on their orbiting paths. You can set starting planets, orbits, size, type or planet, metal density, mass (which affects orbit) and geology of the planet (hills and seas) They can also be saved as templates which can be used later.The PA community is great, you should be able to find a game relatively quickly and there's plenty of let's plays and tutorials on the internet.As of 07/09/2014;The game lacks an offline mode and as an extension saving games. Once Offline Mode comes local saving should follow. Sometimes there is a TiDi effect (Time Dialation) which comes from using Ubers servers. This will slow the game down via increments when the load becomes to great. There are some units and features not implemented yet. There is a thread which can be followed here for the progress of current suggestion and additions to the game: https://forums.uberent.com/threads/confirmed-features-list-2-0.44950/ The game does rely on your computers power, if you have a gaming PC that you set up recently this should run smoothly. If you're running on and old laptop you will struggle on a mid sized single planet game. A tutorial video in the menu is dated and needs to be redone as some units are not present anymore.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Gamma has just made the game feel on par with Supreme Commander - but with the scale of Sins of a Solar Empire.  Until now the game was a little laggy and lacked polish, but you have some basic interface improvements that allow you to jump between planets with ease.  The game is beyond epic in scale almost to a fault but allows you to control unlimited number of units and features a interplanetary war.  For 30 bucks you cant go wrong, the game is only getting better and more polished over time.

												Its...... A game....In all seriousness it is a decent game, the 3D nature make commanding armies an interesting challenge, the visuals are nearly all beautiful and you get a lot of satisfaction from bringing your army to victory over friends or the AI.However, getting to this point has been a struggle, updates are lacking and far between. We were still promised multi-screen support. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Love this game, with friends it's just amazing being able to compete against each other for planetary dominance then fighting over moons and giant planetary death lasers. You have a wide range of fun units to play with depending on what you feel like at the time, you can use weird or straight forward tactics to destroy the enemies commander e.g Unit cannon, sneaky teleporters, orbital strikes, ground strikes, firing a giant death laser at an unexpecting enemy and even pushing a whole moon into the planet they're on! You can build solar systems that you can fight with your friends in, and many more exciting things to do, I still find cool things to do.Problem is that it can be a bit low of frame rate sometimes, but if you have a decent computer you will be able to run it.The AI is not a push over, I have trouble fighting regular AI sometimes. The multiplayer is well done as well, I haven't ever had a problem with it.And its just a load of fun with friends. Easy 8/10-Addicting, diverse, amazing gameplay!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Would have loved to have saved my game but the menu dissappeared... esc button just zoomed out infinitely. Its really annoying when these kinds of games don't have an on-screen way to access the menu, its like RTS 101. My initial impressions are that this game is designed to induce frustration. Its really fun until you realize your bassically fodder for an AI that can multitask, well, like an AI. Good luck ever doing anything, especially using any kind of air units. I couldn't even understand how the radar worked but the second I built an air unit the raids were endless until every one was destroyed. Would have been a lot of fun if the goal was to allow the player to annihilate, rather than be mercilessly annihilated at the hands of a painful interface and unfair mechanics. Hopefully devs wont push multiplayer so hard that they ignore the excellent single player/coop game trying to take hold in the process. I really don't care about twitch or any of that other crap. Also I hate the middle button pan/scroll thing. I have several other buttons on the mouse that would be far better but cannot remap them. Edit: Found out my esc/menu button was bound to the smooth scroll function, so fyi there, completely able to rebind the menu button accidentally. After installing a training mod via Instant Sandbox, I was able to play around and get the hang of things. Not sure if any cheats were installed but I highly recommend the PA Mentor, Build Power, and Instant Sandbox mods to really help figure things out. The next time I tried the initial campaign fight it was a different story and I successfully annihilated the enemy. It was a feeling no RTS has given me since red alert 2. I really, really hope the rest of the campaign is just as good, if it is this is one awesome game!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												For a spiritual successor to SC and TA, this is OK. Nothing more. The game is still fairly bug plagued, isn't very well optimized on some platforms, and is just generally more meh. However, it has two things that will never cease to be amazing every time, and that's the title of the game, you guessed it, Planetary Annihilation. It's satisfying as hell to do, no matter how many times, and that art-style. For being "cartoonish" it's extremely well created and a nice breath of air from all that dark♥♥♥♥♥♥we apparently need in games nowadays.Some of the things I hate so much about this is the same problem SC had with it's AI. As an example, on a two planet system where you're situated on one and the AI on the other, this is the problem i have here, they NEVER move from their base unless it's all destroyed, making focused fire like nukes the easiest way to win every time. They also decide that "I wanna spam one orbital unit all the time because they totally can't destroy it in half a second with one plane!". This makes Galactic War quite tedious when it actually decides to work.This is not to say MP is boring though: it's fast, intense, and definetely the strong point of the game, but I can't help but to ask myself, is PA really that much better than SC - FA or 2 for that matter? I mean yeah, PA has orbital units, but that's about it, it's not polished in any way like the others are, it's no way near as intricate, ten times more glitchy, and generally just not as much fun.TL:DR If you want Supreme Commander with orbital, sure, this is great, but if you don't feel like it's necessary, pick up SC - FA or 2 (1 as well for that matter) for a great price and play the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them!

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								I do not recommend this game for the moment. It was in my wish list from the first day I saw the 'trailer' but it was to expensive (84€ I think). When I saw the price was lower (20 € more or less), i bought it. In 20 minutes I regret it. The game is not like an Age of Empires (they try to sell the game like a futuristic AoE or a similar game) where you can conquest different planets, you conquer one per one (not showed in the 'trailer') and the improvements or the builds that you have made in a planet, are useless for other planet, I mean in a game you play different isolated games. It is so basic with 5 kind of vehicles, 4 bots and 3 planes... so I do not understand WHY IT IS SO SLOW. I have 'played' 6 hours and 3 of this 6 hours i have been waiting. My PC is average, but Arma 3 in HD runs faster than this game. I hope the fix it because I am not going to play anymore until the game runs faster.Other things: -There are games that requires a short explanation like you have to 'download' different data (in the game, not extra data) to build all the buildings, and not the seedy Youtube video that you call Tutorial.- You are waiting for 20 minutes to play a solo game and when you can move you commander, the enemy have build all the buildings, have 300 troops and have read all the Shakespeare books... In the lowest difficult! I will not learn to play if I have to wait 20 minutes to play 4 minutes.In conclusion: 20€ burned... At least I have not bought it when its cost was 84€. If do you want to buy, wait some time. I hope i could return the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Planetary Annihilation is an RTS game of unprecedented scale. Developed from the ground up by Uber Entertainment, it takes strategy gaming to a whole new level.​A little history. PA first appeared on Kickstarter in August of 2012, billed as 'Total Annihilation-inspired gameplay on a planetary scale'. The developers had worked on games such as Total Annihilation and the Supreme Commander series and cashed in big on the nostalgia factor which those names instilled. They were asking for $900,000 and were successfully funded on September 14th, 2012, with $2.2 million. They remain one of Kickstarter's most successful projects to date, being one of only 82 projects (out of 69,400 projects in total) to raise over $1 million.So how does it play?PA is a game of scale. Your battlefield will be entire planets, not mere countries, and this introduces perhaps the most immediately noticeable difference compared to traditional RTS games, that of a spherical map. Players will no longer find themselves boxed in to a square map with artificial, invisible borders. Instead, you will now find yourself with 360 degrees of complete freedom of movement, as well as the ability to zoom in close enough to see your commander's nose hair, or out far enough to view the whole solar system at once.This brings a degree of strategy to base building and defending that is rarely seen in other RTS games, as you can now attack, and be attacked, from any direction at any time.In keeping with the spirit and inspiration of Total Annihilation, PA encourages massive armies and absurdly explosive battles. You are given the tools to build and manage literally thousands of units, there is no unit cap, and this focuses the gameplay on macro expansion and overall 'big picture' tactics, rather than micromanaging small groups of a handful of units.The UI takes some getting used to, but once you get it figured out, you will be impressed with how simple, yet powerful it is.Units can be given a variety of commands, i.e. attack, move, patrol, and the like. They can also be given area commands, which quickly become essential to manage large armies. For example, instead of having a unit patrol simply point to point, you can set an area command of whatever radius you like, and the unit will patrol the entire area selected. You can use this command to cover the entire planet for things like scouts, allowing you to quickly locate your enemy while leaving you free to manage your base. Likewise, you can issue an area attack command, and your units will attack anything they find in the radius of the area you selected.Buildings can also be issued area build orders. For example, when placing a building, you can click and drag the mouse button to queue up an entire line of buildings instead of just the one. This allows you to set up your units with a build queue and then ignore them while you focus on something else.Another UI innovation that PA brings is the picture in picture window. This opens up a secondary small window in your screen, which you can mouse over and use as a second interface. You can control the map, select units, and give orders all within your secondary window at any time just by mousing over it. Tasks such as launching nukes, linking teleporters, or even just keeping an eye on your enemies base while you scout it become a simple matter with this secondary window up. Managing armies and bases that cover entire planets is made easy with these features.​The units in the game are not quite as varied as Total Annihilation or Supreme Commander, however you will find a unit to cover each of your typical RTS roles. The balance of the game is decent, although I imagine it will still be tweaked a lot through upcoming patches, as more people play more games. As with any RTS game designed to be played competitively on ladders, there is always a meta game that evolves, and if you want to be successful in 1v ranked matches it is usually a must to know the current most powerful strategies. If you are like me, though, and play mostly co-op comp stomp or casually with groups of friends, then the game really opens up and allows you to play how you like.The multiplayer interface is nice, but currently the servers are fairly slow, and both hosting and joining games can be a chore at times.  This has gotten progressively better with each update and is at the point that I no longer notice it as any sort of issue in most of my games.The potential for some pretty insane multiplayer games is there, as you can add any number of players in any configuration of teams as you like. I have seen games that were 10v10v10v10v10 and ones that were 3v6v2v8. There is no restrictions and no artifical limits on how you can set up your game, except maybe your system specs.The one thing currently lacking in multiplayer is different game modes. Currently you can set up games as team games, with shared armies, or as free for all games, however you can not choose a supremacy mode, or sandbox mode, or anything else. All games are basically assassination mode, which means that as soon as you lose your commander, you are wiped out entirely, regardless of how many units or buildings you had remaining.The visuals of this game are good, the different planet biomes look fantastic and have a great variety of different ways they can be generated. Things like forest fires and wreckage add to the feeling of complete devastation. The commanders explode in a very satisfying mushroom cloud, and of course, crashing a moon into someone else's planet is always an excellent way to end a game.

Posted: February 6, 2015
												I am one of the kickstarter backers, and this game showed so much promise, looked cool and awesome.Along the way of this game being made i have had my sheer amount of doubts of what would become of this game.Having played the game for many many hours i must say this product has become a wonderful strategy game!The game at this moment and today is the 6th of February 2015 is very good.If you like strategy games you are going to love this, this game has features you have never seen before, and you might need to get used to some, for example:Planet shaped maps, this you will need to get used to, but in time it's awesome.A 3rd and 4th layer of strategy in the form of orbital units and moving to other planets in your system in real time.Blowing up complete planets with a deathstar like super weapon. Building planetary engines on planets and send them like asteroids into another planet and leaving big craters.Wiping out the enemy in so many different ways with such awesomeness, and much more!In my honest opinion, allot of bad things have been said about this game, and at that moment i agreed with allot of them.The developers promised us they would keep working on this titel and make it better, more beautiful, more characteristic, and they kept there word and delivered!!!!! So many things have changed, improved, and new stuff was added and there still working hard on this game and patch it very regulairly.In the short time they made this game, i have nothing but praise for Uber as a developer, not for what they were, but for what they have become and what they made!Buy this game if you like strategy games, i ensure you, you will have lots of fun with this one!

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												I really don't understand why this game is getting so much negativity. I think it's a great game, and it runs great on my ASUS ROG laptop, not to mention my far superior desktop.The developers are working hard to fix things and keep in mind that this is a never before seen scale for an RTS game. It's all brand new territory for developers, and from the looks of it they are doing a pretty awesome job with it.Instead of bashing the game, help support it to keep it alive and growing. Sure there are still some issues for some people but that doesn't mean we should dislike the game entirely. I'm a veteran player coming from the origins of Total Annihilation and the Supreme Commander series, and I've always thoroughly enjoyed seeing the development and growth of these games. Keep the support alive so that the company doesn't collapse like Cavedog and Gas Powered Games did.Give the game its time and the developers will get around to fixing it I'm sure. The game is solid and seeing many improvements, heck a new update just rolled out today as of this writing. So guys, give it some time to keep improving.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												This is indeed a very good game and I recommend it. I bought this game when it was on sale for $5, now. Not saying that this game is so bad that it has to go on sale for 84% off, it is a very good game but for what price you buy it for is your choice. I bought the game twice, once for a friend and once for me and I must say it is a blast, I have barely played any RTS games and he's played a few but we went into the game looking at no videos, no tutorials, nothing. We went in knowing nothing about the game and had a blast, we learned as we went and after a couple games of nonsense it became full scale planetary war between the both of us making it very tense and difficult. The battle of 4 armies is amazing since to win you must develope defence against orbital, naval, land, and air troops otherwise you will greatly get destroyed.Defence:To play this game you need to be somewhat well versed with RTS games and if you aren't it'll be a bit before you get good at it. The game offers 5 types of troops that you can use but 4 versions of them. The 4 versions are the basic orbital, naval, land, and air while the types of troops include orbital, bots, vehicles, planes, and naval troops. When making a base you have to build AA turrets, AN turrets, AO turrets, ect. If you skip one of any of the defences the enemy could have scouted you out with a satellite or scout planes and could easily exploit that weakness for the win.Offence:A good offence is always a good defence. This game can NOT be won if you just sit around making an indestructable base because no matter what you will always have one weakness and if you dont then the enemy will constantly hack at your defences until they cave in. To win you MUST go on the offence, you have to create an army before your enemy does and start attacking immediately. Scout their base, find their weakness, exploit it. Be unlike me, I feel bad when I do this so I lose many of my games, I am slowly learning to stop doing this. You must attack to be victorious. There are many strategies, build and use a teleporter, use unit cannons, or just make a base on THEIR planet!Planets:The planets are very diverse and randomly generated. You will never play on the same map even if you choose the same system to play on. There are planets that are like Earth with trees and oceans, there's lava planets full of oceans filled with lava instead of water, ice planets covered in..... well..... ice!, there's the "Metal Planet" A.K.A death star, and not to leave out the gold mine called a gas planet. There are so many planets to go on and many ways to defend and offend on them.Pros:- Many things to build- Progressive building- Control of multiple planets- Difficult economy- Nice effects- Simplistic graphics- Fog of WarCons:- Slightly unbalanced gameplay- Poorly optimized- Large amounts of lag when armies begin to grow- Horrible bugs

Posted: January 17, 2015
												Planetary Annihilation is an RTS game of unprecedented scale. Developed from the ground up by Uber Entertainment, it takes strategy gaming to a whole new level.​A little history. PA first appeared on Kickstarter in August of 2012, billed as 'Total Annihilation-inspired gameplay on a planetary scale'. The developers had worked on games such as Total Annihilation and the Supreme Commander series and cashed in big on the nostalgia factor which those names instilled. They were asking for $900,000 and were successfully funded on September 14th, 2012, with $2.2 million. They remain one of Kickstarter's most successful projects to date, being one of only 82 projects (out of 69,400 projects in total) to raise over $1 million.So how does it play?PA is a game of scale. Your battlefield will be entire planets, not mere countries, and this introduces perhaps the most immediately noticeable difference compared to traditional RTS games, that of a spherical map. Players will no longer find themselves boxed in to a square map with artificial, invisible borders. Instead, you will now find yourself with 360 degrees of complete freedom of movement, as well as the ability to zoom in close enough to see your commander's nose hair, or out far enough to view the whole solar system at once.This brings a degree of strategy to base building and defending that is rarely seen in other RTS games, as you can now attack, and be attacked, from any direction at any time.In keeping with the spirit and inspiration of Total Annihilation, PA encourages massive armies and absurdly explosive battles. You are given the tools to build and manage literally thousands of units, there is no unit cap, and this focuses the gameplay on macro expansion and overall 'big picture' tactics, rather than micromanaging small groups of a handful of units.The UI takes some getting used to, but once you get it figured out, you will be impressed with how simple, yet powerful it is.Units can be given a variety of commands, i.e. attack, move, patrol, and the like. They can also be given area commands, which quickly become essential to manage large armies. For example, instead of having a unit patrol simply point to point, you can set an area command of whatever radius you like, and the unit will patrol the entire area selected. You can use this command to cover the entire planet for things like scouts, allowing you to quickly locate your enemy while leaving you free to manage your base. Likewise, you can issue an area attack command, and your units will attack anything they find in the radius of the area you selected.Buildings can also be issued area build orders. For example, when placing a building, you can click and drag the mouse button to queue up an entire line of buildings instead of just the one. This allows you to set up your units with a build queue and then ignore them while you focus on something else.Another UI innovation that PA brings is the picture in picture window. This opens up a secondary small window in your screen, which you can mouse over and use as a second interface. You can control the map, select units, and give orders all within your secondary window at any time just by mousing over it. Tasks such as launching nukes, linking teleporters, or even just keeping an eye on your enemies base while you scout it become a simple matter with this secondary window up. Managing armies and bases that cover entire planets is made easy with these features.​The units in the game are not quite as varied as Total Annihilation or Supreme Commander, however you will find a unit to cover each of your typical RTS roles. The balance of the game is decent, although I imagine it will still be tweaked a lot through upcoming patches, as more people play more games. As with any RTS game designed to be played competitively on ladders, there is always a meta game that evolves, and if you want to be successful in 1v ranked matches it is usually a must to know the current most powerful strategies. If you are like me, though, and play mostly co-op comp stomp or casually with groups of friends, then the game really opens up and allows you to play how you like.The multiplayer interface is nice, but currently the servers are fairly slow, and both hosting and joining games can be a chore at times.  This has gotten progressively better with each update and is at the point that I no longer notice it as any sort of issue in most of my games.The potential for some pretty insane multiplayer games is there, as you can add any number of players in any configuration of teams as you like. I have seen games that were 10v10v10v10v10 and ones that were 3v6v2v8. There is no restrictions and no artifical limits on how you can set up your game, except maybe your system specs.The one thing currently lacking in multiplayer is different game modes. Currently you can set up games as team games, with shared armies, or as free for all games, however you can not choose a supremacy mode, or sandbox mode, or anything else. All games are basically assassination mode, which means that as soon as you lose your commander, you are wiped out entirely, regardless of how many units or buildings you had remaining.The visuals of this game are good, the different planet biomes look fantastic and have a great variety of different ways they can be generated. Things like forest fires and wreckage add to the feeling of complete devastation. The commanders explode in a very satisfying mushroom cloud, and of course, crashing a moon into someone else's planet is always an excellent way to end a game.

												I am one of the kickstarter backers, and this game showed so much promise, looked cool and awesome.Along the way of this game being made i have had my sheer amount of doubts of what would become of this game.Having played the game for many many hours i must say this product has become a wonderful strategy game!The game at this moment and today is the 6th of February 2015 is very good.If you like strategy games you are going to love this, this game has features you have never seen before, and you might need to get used to some, for example:Planet shaped maps, this you will need to get used to, but in time it's awesome.A 3rd and 4th layer of strategy in the form of orbital units and moving to other planets in your system in real time.Blowing up complete planets with a deathstar like super weapon. 												I bought this game months ago on a whim but didn't bother trying it until this weekend. To put it plainly, this is the game I've been waiting for. I've always loved RTSes and was waiting for the day Civilization made it to this level of play. I'm glad I didn't wait. Even in beta, it's incredible. The graphics are crisp and responsive (set to moderate on my GE70) and the gameplay is fantastic. The controls are easy to figure out and there is very little learning curve. I had started playing Eve for a while but got tired of the learning curve, not to mention it's just not an RTS or TBS.As someone who rarely plays games, I was unsure about paying for a game that was still in alpha but I'm glad I did. This game ranks with Seven Kingdoms: AA as one of the best strategy games of all time. I can't wait for the totally finished product. Considering how far it's come in so little time, I know I won't be disappointed.

												I bought this when it was like $30 and wish I had waited, when I bought it was still in early stages of development and the game ran a little clunky and there was a lot going on to handle, plus switching and deciding planets was the insanely annoying.  If you are into Commander or real time strategy I would say buy, but buyer beware there is a lot going on at once and it is hard to control everything going on in the battlefield.  The AI isn't the strongest on lower difficulties and mainly just gives you trouble on their homeworld.  I never got deep into the game as I like turn based strategy, but definitely a good pick-up I'll have to play more anyone who is into space strategy would love this.  6/10 overall since when I bought it, for the genre I would say 8/10.  I wish the combat and management system where slightly easier to control so I didn't have to do so many damn mouse clicks, but the combat and winning is fast so it is fun for a quick play.  Definitely recommend to anyone who's a casual gamer or someone more serious if you are into conquering games.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hi fellow gamers, I'm sure you've all played many games that are stratergy and this one should take the cake so far.  If you've played Total Annihilation or Supreme Commander you already have a feel for this game but there's two huge differences!  There are no unit caps and you are battleing it out in a living solar system. The worlds not flat and you can travel through space in minutes to reach a brand new and perhaps uninhabited planet to extort.  The other main points of this game are massive scale macro and micro management of units and buildings. Artilery, aircraft, naval fleets, and various ground forcers all create the basic combat groups.  Late game units go beyond those even and add in satellite combat in the upper atmospheres of planets or even strapping some giant engines onto a nearby planet and making a very nice planet destroying machine! =]  A few things to note though, this is extrememly resource intensive game (hardware wise) and is intended for next generation computing.  So if you dont have a fancy computer you're going to want one =)

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Now I had my eye on this game for quite some time, but I was not willing on spending the original $60 on it. I opened steam one day and what do I see, Planetary Annihilation for $30. I bought that instantly and have had no regrets in buying it. Planetary Annihilation takes real time strategy games to a whole new level with orbital and planetary warefare. You can attack from any angle you want in order to beat your enemy (in my case only ai's cause I'm not that great yet :O). If that doesn't work why not just jump to a moon, construct some rockets on it and launch it and them. The way you rotate around the map (planets) and then you will be looking at your base from a different angle is a bit weird at first but after about 3 hours I was used to it. The graphics were also a big change for me as I'm not usually a fan of cartoonish style graphics, but again I got used to it after a little while. I have encounted a few bugs and I always have a problem with units being slighty delayed. So if this would be a problem for you wait a little while but definitely buy it when it's fully released.After actually playing this I would have paid $50-$60 so I would recommend any RTS fan to purchase this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												I've been a long time strategy gamer, and have mixed feelings about it. There are things that I love, and things that I hate.I will also repeatedly compare this game to Supreme Commander, as it's very similar (it is a spiritual successor).What I Love:Runs beautifullyGood communityGreat graphics, UI, mod support.Hits a sweet-spot of occupation - there's always something to do, but I never feel so overloaded that I can't manage it.There's excellent sets of tools for management, such as the secondary map (which is a beautiful idea).Few bugsWell done economies. I personally find it a little resource-rich, but it's pretty good.Excellent general gameplay - on-planet gameplay is very well done, and battles are always fun and exciting.Cons:Game-breaking units. This is the big one. In a good RTS, every strategy should be counterable - there should never be a strategy that has no way of being defeated. This game has too many.-> SXX laser platform - there is no defense to them coming in above your commander and getting off a single shot each. I have had countless fun and even games end with an enemy simply bringing them directly above the commander, and there is no good way of preventing it. It's no fun.-> Halleys - it's too difficult to counter a planet in motion (nothing can get to it other than teleports, and if they have halleys you probably don't have a teleporter).-> Halleys and catalysts are, in my opinion, too cheap. There cost would be better if doubled.Storing resources is also a bit too easy. Dividing storage capacity by 4 would help.Overall, this is a great game, especially for the beginning RTS player who wishes to get into serious RTS. Its economy is padded, meaning production of units is usually easy, but can still offer challenges. It runs like a dream, and is a truly beautiful game from a graphics perspective. Battles are fun and entertaining.However, once you become reasonably good at RTS games I would have to advise Supreme Commander over this game. The economy is a little too padded for competitive gameplay, and there are enough units that can be exploited, especially in late-game, to destroy advanced and many-planet games.If you've never played RTS games before, pick it up. You'll enjoy it, and it will teach well many of the skills necessary to play RTSs well. However, if you consider yourself at least moderately experienced an RTS player, I would recommend other games over it, and to be aware of the problems associated with it before a purchase.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a game I'd recommend to any RTS fan. The game does have a bit of a learning curve to it. It would be best to read up on guides, watch video tutorials or practice with some friends. The stradegy involved is completely different from your average RTS so using the "normal" tactics wouldn't be recommended. Though this game does have its flaws:The factions have no difference from one another except being a different name and colour. There is no in depth lore at the time of this post, but the game has a ton of potential. The potential storyline could be amazing if Uber plays their cards right and not rely so heavily on their backers from Kickstarter to write it for them.This game isn't 100% done and still has some A.I. issues where they could be inactive and have their commanders sit there as  you steamroll them with endless waves of troops. Or the troops go in completely different directions and can get stuck into buildings/enviornment.The best things Uber can do for this game are:To fix the bugs for the A.I. and make some commanders have special abilities or act differently.Develop the lore and possibly a single-player campaign and not exclusively give the backers a chance to add ideas to the lore and cut off everyone else. Diversify the Factions by at least giving different models or different troops or specialities (i.e. Making 1 faction's air troops more speed/damage/health or having 1 type more developed than the last.)Of course I'm going to expect Uber to do anything listed above, all that was posted was a mere suggestion from a lover and near worshipper of the RTS genre. If you have a chance to get the game you should, it is an absolute fun time to play with, especially with friends. Though it would be best to wait for the full release, I only bought the game because I have high hopes for the game and want to support Uber.*Please note that by the time that this game is fully released, anything listed could already be fixed and/or intgrated into the game.*

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												I picked this up for me and my son and we just played two games against each other and we had a blast.  It does not have all the features of other AAA games in this genre but with the steam sale, this game is more than worth the 5 bucks it cost.  Being new to the game I might just not know how to do everything but I felt the following was missing:- No way to queue your build orders.  You start with a commander who builds things and walks very slow.  Later you can build other builders and get around this but I found it odd I could not queue my commander to build three things.  It makes the start of the game a babysitting job where you just follow him from building to building.- Unit descriptions need some work.  I assumed an orbital defense satellite would shot down a nuke, I was wrong.- Planets seem to rotate on you for no reason.  What was up/north one minute becomes right/east in another minute and disorientates you.  I could not find a way to rotate the planet manually but again, I am new to the game and maybe I just could not find it.  Other than that, it was great fun.  For the $5, I would recommend it if you have a friend to play with.

The units are huge and the planets are tiny and lacking in character. I've played it maybe 6 times and probably won't go back.I can honestly say that this feels unfinished and is currently the biggest entertainment disappointment that I have experienced thus far.I still recommend the game at the current sale price as it is very fun for a short time and may be great for new players. But having "been there done that and done it better", it's not for me.

There is a game journal option on the main menu that will go over some of the basics, but there is no actual tutorial for the game which I thought was rather dissapointing. Despite this, the game itself is fun as other reviewers have said you destroy planets and thats about it. I would not buy the game at full price but if it is on sale and you want a decent RTS to play to kill some time I would get it.P.S. There is no campaign of any kind so don't expect any sort of story or real explanation to the game.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												This is a difficult review to write. The game is an awesome idea, interplanetary battles with amazing lazers and missiles you can strap to a moon to catapult it somewhere. However this game is not perfect.Pros-Multiplayer works well-Singleplayer Galactic War mode is great fun-Possible to make your own system to battle on-Quite addictive-Constantly updatedCons - This is where the bad bit begins-The system requirement-The glitches (so many, everywhere)-Not many varients of units,you have the tank, flame tank, anti air tank and thats all-End game orbital war is painful and slow-Not enough players to fill up the multiplayer lobby'sThis is the worstTo begin with it is interesting, but as time goes on you realise that 90% of singleplayer games are exactly the same, same tactics win everytime.Now with all cons why do I recommend it? the 10% of games that aren't repetative are awesome. If you feel like an RTS game where you spam LOADS of units (and have a good computer) this is the game for you. However If you are after more tactics and more complex and interesting gamplay the Supreme Commander series is perfect.This game is not in full release like it says on the steam page, it is still in development and maybe they will fix the issues so keep an eye on this game but only get it on a good deal. Overwise, go for supreme commander forged alliance (The steam advertising is pathetic) which is half the price of Planetary Annihilation.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
												I wrote a review for this game already, saying that I didnt recommend it. However as you read this now, you may have realised i am now recommending it. I was one of the many who funded this game on kickstarter, something like 3 years ago, and i was honestly disappointed with the outcome. However as of late i was playing some total annihilation and decided that this game deserved another go. Before now the game didnt run smoothly, it constantly crashed and that prevented me from seeing the mechanics this game had to offer. They have seemed to have fixed the problem and i play the game regularly. The mechanics are great, I could describe them in detail and waste your life or i could tell you that they are like total annihilation in the 21st century. The graphics are perfect and simple, the satisfaction of watching your buildings being built is undescribable and the combat is smooth and great + the soundtrack is up to par. The choice of commanders is great, they seem to cover every play style, whether you like relentlessly slaughtering your enemies in the earky game or conducting a large scale battle in the late. The explosions are wonderful aswell, especially when planets collide, not quite universe sandbox 2, but very good none the less.Things i dont like: The movement of units that travel between planets seems grainy and undefined, especially when your moving a planet.The planets don't rotate as time moves forward which strips the realism out from your hands.You cannot collide planets into the sun.Very little solar system customization. The Halley's (engines you use to move planets) are available way too early in the game and provide an unbelieveable easy victory for your combatant. They seemingly havent tried to balance this at all.However I think that this game's positives outweigh its faults and therefore give this game a somewhat clean bill of health. Possibly has a mild cough.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I highly recommend this game, however, for those of you with... not the best of computers- like myself, be warned, your computer WILL turn into a 747 engine. Even with graphics turned down to the lowest settings, my computer is very loud when this game is running. With this being said, the game is highly addictive, and as slow as it runs for me (not the game, it's my computer) I still feel the need to finish- despite my problem with my graphics (once again- MY COMPUTER- not the game). The strategy aspect of this game is intense, fast paced, and even if you aren't the best at RTS's- like myself- it is easy to recover if you screw yourself. This game is amazing, support the devs and buy this game NOW. This game boldly goes where no RTS has gone before. Taking the fight to other planets, turning moons into missiles, creating orbital strike satellites, powerful upgrades to your vehicles; generators and metal extractors. This is one of the best RTS's I've played.What are you waiting for? But this game now, easily worth the money!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Ok, so I got this game for free through a deal on a website where you had to follow certain steam and facebook pages, etc.I am so glad I got it for free because I don't think it would have been worth the $99 it used to cost, let alone $29.99.I know I only have less than an hour played, but in a game like this it doesn't take much longer than 30 minutes to know if you are going to like a game or not,The graphics are pretty, I will give this game that, but that's about it.First, when you log in, you are greeted with ads.  Boo.Secondly, there is no campaign. That is to say, there's no story mode like other RTS games, and that's important to me because I suck in most any kind of PVP environment in any game, so I love a good single player story driven campaign mode.  This game does not have that.  Instead it has Galactic War (or something like that) where you start off with basic tech and work your way from planet to planet hoping to find additional tech and loadouts.  Oh, and you can only have 4 active tech at one time, so your SoL if you want to have more.Thirdly, it seems every "race" in this game is the same units just different colors.  The only thing that seems to differentiate is the commanders you have who start everything off.  Fourthly, unless I missed it, I found no tutorial mode to get you used to the game, it just plunks you right in Galactic mode and you have to figure stuff out for yourself.Fifthly, stuff just did not make sense to me cost wise through metal and energy.  For example, it appeared to me I had, to start off, a max amount of metal of 1.5k.  Well, one of the buildings, I think the air one that creates satellites and stuff, cost 2700 metal, yet I was able to build it.  I also could not find a way to increase the cap on metal, but it appears it really does not matter.  If things are different then they appear, the game does not tell you. Again, you have to figure stuff out for yourself.Lastly, gameplay.  While the game felt very RTS in the way grouping, moving, building, and attacking worked, I really didn't feel excited about exploring and attacking the enemy.  I built up my forces with several different units, grouped them up, and set out to find my foe.  I found them eventually, but when I did, it wasn't exciting or scary or anything. It was just, "Ok."  The terrain is an actual spherical planet you travel on, and to me feels barren, generic, and very boring.  PS: I don't know how effective walls are but I built a crapton of them which takes a long time, and I saw no way to queue multiple walls (unless I miss something, but I cannot stress, the game doesn't teach you anything) and had to take my 3 builders and commander and build each wall separately.Out of a rating of 10, I would rate this game a 3.  I enjoyed the Star Wars RTS way better than this generic game.  The WHOLE game just feels lazily done and generic to me. Too much of the same thing between the terrain and the units.

I'm always insecure by what a unit will do, if my radar works, how I can transport my units and just how the whole thing works.Great potencial, but very bad execution, go buy Forged Alliance if you want a complete experence or SC2 for something more polished and simple.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												My original review of PA was made in a fury after one too many crashes, which was solved after I bumped up my virtual RAM (Which is still a tad ridiculous, as it went from 4GB to 12GB but still).Summary: Under the right circumstances, this game is a blast. However, those on the lower spectrum of the minimum specs (specifically those with anything under 8GB of RAM), as well as those looking for a single player campaign would be better off shying away. I'm also a tad hesitant to recommend even on sale since those who backed this game from the very beginning and who paid $100+ still haven't gotten promised content. The dev prematurely released this game and has since abandoned it, then did a kickstarter for another game.Gameplay: Ever wanted to blow up planets with a giant death star? This is your game. You spawn on a planet with your commander and, using the resources of energy and metal, grow an army and build a base, then eventually visit other planets and take other commanders out of play. There are four main types of units; bots, vehicular, aerial, and naval. Each have strenghts and weakness, for example vehicles move slower but complete objectives faster, vice versa for aerial units, and bots are middle ground. There are some balancing issues, most notably the gap of ease of access between metal and energy. I hardly found myself ever running out of energy, but metal was a different story. Pathing is also a major issue. Finally, there are some glitches to be found, such as units refusing to do something.Graphics: It's an RTS. They're good enough but no Crysis by any stretchOptimization: This is where this game shines, really. Much of the money for this game went to servers and it absolutely shows. I saw a YouTube video of a 35 man FFA (no AI) and there was no real lag. But that's not even close to the max ammount of players. Even in a system with a lot of planets and thousands of units roaming around, I have yet to notice major lag and fps drops besides the occasional hang. (However, I have a fairly high end system, so like I said above if you're barely meeting the recommended specs, wait until you upgrade your PC)Misc: No real single player. Galactic War is a real let down. However, you can always do a local multi match against AI (Who are pretty good). Galaxy editor is really fun and allows for fun gameplay combinations. Final Verdict: If you have a group of friends, or even just one friend who play this with you, this game is great fun. That being said, if you pay full price for this game you're getting ripped off. $6 is a good price for this game.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's the RTS we have been waiting for.  Simple resources, massive armies, great defences and awesome superweapons! I like the art style, it works wonders for the scale of the game.  The units make sense and have short, accurate tool-tips.  Tech progression is straightforeward but well done. The AI is fairly cleaver and diverse, it will keep you busy. And the Picture in a Picture tool is actually incredible! Seems like such a small detail, but I cannot get enough of it!  And this is all before I've played matches against friends, or figured out all the keybindings and features.  Extremely playable and fun as of this review during Early Access. As an overly brief description, its a game of pumping out units to smash into your opponent's armies/bases with a multi-planet scale.  Red Alert 2 meets Sins of a Solar Empire, along with ROBOTS, to make Planetary Annihilation.If you are a fan of Real Time Strategies, you owe it to yourself to get this game. You will not regret it.  (If you'd like to compare, previous favorite RTSs of mine were Sins of a Solar Empire, Red Alert 2, Age of Empires 2, and CnC Tiberium Sun.  PA already has earned its spot next to those titles for me.) I don't often write reviews, but this game deserves it!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Did you like games like Civilization V, Supreme Commander, Total Annihilation? Then you will absoloutley love this game to bits. I have only had this game for around 3 days and my hours tell how much I love the game!Gameplay:The gameplay is great. You can always take a different route in game, maybe you want to be one of those guys who just bombs the hell out of everyone else, maybe you want to build up you army of death lasers or even nukes, well you can do it all infact you can even launch a moon into another planet absoloutley blowing it to pieces!The landscapes are not flat in any shape or form and the game has around 5 preset solar systems you can choose for your game, but once you're bored of them you can create your own!Also the matches, they can go on for ages that is the best part for example last night I was in  a 2 hour long match and I did not get bored, so much to do, so much to worry about.Graphics:The graphics are simply amazing for what they need to be, about 4-5 different graphical settings allowing from low range PC's to high range PC's. They suit the genre exacly nice and cartoony and they all blend well.The UI is also nice, it does not get in the way and is easy to find what you need.Conclusion:Overall I would have to say for a definite I recommend this game for anyone who likes the RTS genre, its amazing graphics, very long gameplay, variety of things to do and overall fun as hell!*Still is early access so does have some bugs, but good thing is they are being actively fixed and no major ones!*

								Absolutely recommend. This game, while still a bit rough (Dec. 2013), is a blast to play with friends. The variety of tactics you can pursue is solid, and the scale of the world in which you can play in is great.The game is about defeating the enemy commander which is all you spawn with. You build up an economy to support your military which then goes on the prowl. Meanwhile, their commander may have gone to another planet to hide. Scale! content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Good for competitive and relatively multitasking oriented strategy gamers. Bad for casual gamers who want to have fun and mess around. If you have friends you have a double win but if you prefer playing on your own and have a casual stroll, you might wanna skip it.I have around 300 hours of alpha/beta hours(before converting to steam a few days ago) and plenty of videos on YT and even though I loved TA and SupCom, PA became too competitive for me. I've been messing around in the single player Galactic War and that is okay but I'd love a mode with challenges or something you can play casually since there will be no campaign.Either way I would definitely recommend the game as it is a successor to TA in most aspects and you can enjoy it. Some may enjoy it more than others but thats the case with any game!

content:
Posted: February 5
												I can say this game is probably the best real time strategy I have ever played. Its has some kinks, but once you get the hang of it its very good.Other RTS games I have put a decent ammount of hours into inclue Age Of Empires 2 and halo wars, so im going to draw comparisons with those games to build this review.Age of empires is good, but it has glaring flaws. The units are dumb and need frequent commands, and there is a population limit, preventing people from building huge armys. The building system is nice however, as it allows the player to put building where they want, and build more complex basesHalo Wars has a low population limit, which really bummed me out in the later portions of matches because my armies could not grow according to the ammount of recources I was generating. And the bases where small, and didnt give the players much freedom when deciding the location of buildings.Planetary Annihilation takes the best aspects of the two, and kills off the problems each of them had. Freedom when building, mostly autonomous units, no population limit, all features I love in an RTS. I can make armies of biblical proportions, have entire planets designated to harvesting resources for me, while I use the resources to build machinery that lets me crash a moon into its home planet, destroying my enemies in the process.Pros--NO UNIT POPULATION CAP (And a constant build mode on unit factories)-Lots of control over units-Almost every unit can do tasks automatically-Can build custom solar systems to fight inCons--The program itself does not run very smoothly. Long load times, temporary freezing in menues, etc.-Multiplayer can be hard to get started when playing on big solar systems-User interface is not very straight forward, but easy to use once you learn it.Overall I highly recomend this game, especially if you have friends to play it with.

content:

Early Access Review
								I backed this at kickstarter cause i thought it was a cool idea, but now that i actually play it, it's not that good.Gameplay example:I joined the game and instantly built everything i needed to get an orbital launcher, then i launch my commander to another planet to have him safe.I start building an base on the second planet because the AI is flooding my first base with a ****load of planes. (I'm talking 200+ here).My first base is completely gone and my second base is looking good. I tell my workers to put electricity and metal miners all over the planet. (The planet is small, so yes, it's possible)I build an army that i thought would wreck the AI, and then i realize. How am i gonna get them there?I spent about an hour building about 500+ spaceships to tow the army to the AI base.I get there, and the AI is completely crazy! It's got about 800+ planes, a few workers and millions of structures. (Everything from defenses to orbital launchers)I send in my army, drop them, and then the lag starts. 0-15 fps for about a minute. When the lag stops i realize that i've got like 10 vehicles left. And the worst thing is, the AI never stop building!I put army after army in there to hope that they will find a way to kill the AI, and it works! Just when i'm about to send in everything i got, the game crashes.Good Game.If the game gets updated so that it's funnier and not totally unbeatable, then maybe i'll change my review, but right now, it's not playable or fun.
